Oreste's birthplace was Argos, and on the death of his father, the king (who was, incidentally, murdered), he was taken away to Athens to be raised by a noble family. When he returns to Argos, he cannot feel a part of the city, not because he is guilty, but because he is innocent, whereas all those citizens born in Argos and living there have supposedly been born into guilt. The whole point of the play, an attack on the Church and religion, especially Catholicism, aligns well with Sartre's atheism.

The entire city of Argos is in perpetual mourning and repentance for a murder they were unaware of. For those who were present, guilt is theirs for not having prevented the atrocity. The Queen's mournful clothing and black funereal makeup emphasize the point: there is no happiness in the city. They are allowing themselves to be ruled by the past, trapped in a time-warp, not moving forward, not even seeing their futures. Sartre's exaggerated portrayal of the real world and its religion is evident throughout the play.

Religion suggests we are guilty simply because we are human and live governed by the murder of Christ, which they claim we must repent. A significant attribute is the plague of flies around and in Argos, enhancing the picture of being totally enclosed and "attacked" by something Sartre implies is all in the mind. His ability to shock his audience was powerful, ensuring their attention and reaction.

Sartre places a god on earth, suggesting that we are no greater than them, and that producing miracles does not justify their power over us or our servitude under them. This aligns with the theme that religion, especially Catholicism, does not have the power Sartre believes it to have. The plague of flies and the city's mourning reflect this belief, as they symbolize the mind's power over perceived divine intervention. Through these elements, Sartre critiques the notion that religion justifies human guilt and servitude, emphasizing a more human-centered perspective.

However, Dora maintains that if Kaliayev had thrown the bomb, the revolutionary organization would have lost its support. La Chute powerfully portrays the themes of guilt and judgment throughout the novel, not only through the words used but also by the nature of the settings. A lawyer from Paris, Clemenceau, falls into a sense of awareness when he hears a laugh as he crosses a bridge, feeling as though the whole world is laughing at him. This reaction is reminiscent of a historical event when Clemanceau heard a young woman fall into the river as she committed suicide, and did nothing to help, continuing to walk by.

The novel unfolds as a monologue, with Clemanceau confiding his past life to a stranger in a bar in Amsterdam. He reveals that he used to like defending widowers and orphans, but later realizes he did not genuinely care for these people, only wanting to remain on the right side of the law. When Clemanceau begins to think more deeply about life, he concludes that it is futile and is haunted by the laugh he heard, realizing his hypocrisy during his time in Paris.

Upon realizing that his motives for helping others were "wrong," Clemanceau decides to play the fool, contemplating absurd acts such as puncturing the tires of wheelchairs. It is when he understands that absolute innocence is impossible that he decides to aim his life towards absolute guilt. He believes that by confessing his absolute guilt, no one will be able to laugh at him behind his back. However, this belief is shaken when he thinks he sees a drowning woman in the sea from the transatlantic liner. The guilt he feels for not attempting to save the woman who committed suicide in Paris remains with him throughout the novel.

In existentialist terms, guilt is a characteristic that often accompanies duplicity. When seeking to come to terms with the absurdity of human existence—the inherent conflict between man's desire to seek truth and the incomprehensible nature of the world, as well as his own mortality—one consequence is the portrayal of a guilty nature. In an attempt to revolt against the absurdity of life, individuals often engage in duplicity, refusing to accept life's inherent absurdity.

"La Chute" explores various types of guilt assigned to different characters. Clarence's guilt, for instance, is multifaceted. As a lawyer in Paris, his previous life was marked by a sense of 'oneness' and false innocence. However, once he hears the scream on the bridge, which triggers memories of his past, Clarence realizes that this life was indeed duplicitous. His earlier image in the mirror now appears double to him because he failed to recognize the essential nature of the human condition, leading a life that superficially appeared altruistic but was, in reality, driven by a desire for control over others.

In an effort to overcome this guilt, Clarence attempts to overtly demonstrate his double character by leading a life of self-satisfaction and debauchery. Despite these efforts, he remains unable to rid himself of his guilt. Consequently, he travels to Amsterdam, a place associated with Nazi atrocities, to perform his newly created role as 'juge-pénitent.' In this role, he aims to exorcize his guilt by exposing it to others and regaining a sense of superiority he lost. He wishes his interlocutor were a policeman so that his confession would be acted upon, not for punishment, but to regain his self-esteem through the act of judging others.

To vividly demonstrate the sense of guilt he feels after his 'fall,' Clarence references a legal concept, referring to the friends he once dominated. This further illustrates the profound impact of his duplicity and the lingering guilt that permeates his existence.

In his play "Caligula," Camus revisits the questions he had earlier raised in "Le mythe de Sisyphe" concerning the absurdity of life and our acceptance of this. The way in which he portrays Caligula shows the perversion of the attributes expressed in "Le mythe de Sisyphe" as desirable. Cherea, used by Camus as a counterbalance to Caligula's absolute nature, is not illogical but realizes the value of life, suggesting his rightness.

Following the death of Drusilla, Caligula has come to understand the true nature of man's existence: "Man's mortality is now painfully clear to him, as is the futility of his life." Consequently, Caligula has grasped the absurdity of our condition—the fact that we can never possess the world and never achieve full clarity leaves him with a sense of anguish. However, the reality is that Caligula can never make man mortal, and thus unable to avoid death, he becomes death. Le Mythe de Sisyphe is a novel bound with duplicity, particularly evident in its exploration of the main theme: that life is futile yet worth living to the full. The central themes of the novel, absurdity and suicide, are intricately intertwined and examined throughout. Camus starts by attempting to define the absurd, which he considers the foundation of his work. He criticizes other philosophers for not recognizing the potential of the absurd, constantly using it as a conclusion instead of a starting point. Absurdity arises when an everyday object loses its everyday meaning.

Camus argues that people need 'clairvoyance' or lucidity, suggesting that people crave and require knowledge. However, he shares the Cartesian view that the only certainty is 'I think, therefore I am,' emphasizing that our knowledge of certain things is beyond our grasp. The disparity between the quest for fundamental truth and what we can be certain of remains unaltered.

The creation of the 'absurd' man involves a process where an object is first removed from its everyday meaning. During an everyday task, the meaning of the act is suddenly withdrawn, making the futility of the action overwhelmingly apparent. Camus describes the realization of time passing and the self-hatred that arises from not making the most of one's life. When life is stripped of the meaning we usually attribute to it, every act appears futile. Camus eloquently describes this solitude and isolation as akin to a light that doesn't shine.

Having grasped the absurdity of life, Camus notes that some people attempt to deny it by taking a leap of faith, often seeking refuge in religion. This response, according to Camus, is a vain attempt to escape the inherent meaninglessness of existence.

In Sartrean thinking, Oreste begins the play as a blank slate, his project yet to crystallize, and his choices determining his course in life still undefined. Pédagogue has taught him to believe in traditional and customary ideas, instilling a false sense of freedom in him. Up to this point, Oreste has acted like a 'free spirit,' making no real choices and failing to realize his project.

Through the first part of the play, Oreste shows signs of innocent bad faith. He has no past experience and believes in predestination, an idea Sartre rejects, arguing that we control our destiny through our choices. Oreste also dreams of finding his past in Argos, another instance of innocent bad faith, as we cannot acquire an essence by assuming a social role. He believes he could develop by assuming a leadership role in Argos.

Oreste starts in a position of bad faith and moves throughout the play towards authenticity and freedom of consciousness (pour-soi). This transformation is symbolized by Electre's acceptance of him as Oreste, her brother, rather than Philèbe. The primary influence and catalyst for his change is his observation of others' bad faith in the play. The people of Argos are deluded, using their delusion to escape the anguish of individual freedom and responsibility. They are like unchanging objects determined by external forces, with their present and future dictated by a past event—alleged complicity in a murder. Even the children are brought up in guilt.

Electre's behavior also plays a crucial role in transforming Oreste. Initially, she seems to refute his self-remorse, attempting to expose the bad faith of others. At the 'fête des morts,' she tries to awaken the people to their freedom, only to be interrupted by Jupiter's religious parody performance, moving a stone in a miraculous display of his divine power. This event serves as a turning point, helping Oreste and the audience to confront their own bad faith and move towards authenticity.

Guilt and judgment are recurring themes in several of Camus' works, notably in the account of Clamence's fall. This narrative is less about recounting an event and more accurately described as an "état de l'âme," in which Clamence is imbued with guilt and a desire to judge others. This guilt is also subtly alluded to in various nuances throughout the play, reflecting the universal guilt of mankind. Clamance introduces himself as a "juge-pénitent," a term clarified only at the end of the novel, which demonstrates Clamence's tendency to judge people, his desire to feel superior, and his penchant for apportioning guilt to those he encounters.

Clamence's former profession as a lawyer supports this theme, as it placed him in an environment rife with guilt, defending or trying to prove people guilty of crimes, and giving him a sense of superiority. In the courtroom, he often felt superior to the judge, deriving satisfaction from looking down on people and judging the cases. Guilt and judgment are inherent in the legal system itself.

In Paris, Clamence led what he believed was a happy and satisfying life, enjoying helping people and the satisfaction it gave him. This existence continued until a laugh on a bridge shattered his world view, making him aware of what he perceived as the true state of the world. This realization broke his current existence and made him acutely aware of his own guilt.

In "Caligula," the story unfolds through the interactions of its characters, each with their own negative or positive valuation that either evokes sympathy for Caligula or challenges the audience's perception of him. Caligula remains the sole focus of attention throughout the play, and it is his actions, thoughts, and words that drive the narrative. This focalization ultimately leaves it to the reader or audience to decide whether they harbor any sympathy or admiration for Caligula, with our own values and emotions playing a significant role from the beginning. Caligula's mourning for his sister Drusilla, though mistakenly perceived by his courtiers, may elicit sympathy for him. When his patricians think he is ill or mentally disturbed, the audience may also feel sympathy for Caligula, especially if they themselves do not like being unwell.

Caligula's character embodies Camus' theme of the absurd, as Adèle King describes it: "the insoluble opposition between what (man) is and what man desires." From Drusilla's death until his own, Caligula becomes acutely aware of the mortality of human beings, feeling the futility of human existence. He murders indiscriminately, causes famine, and even kills his own lover. Man desires immortality and happiness, but with the knowledge of the absurd, Caligula understands that such goals are impossible. Yet, in a revolt against the absurd, Caligula attempts to achieve the impossible, believing that if he can possess the moon, he will transcend the gods and reign over an empire where the impossible is paramount. Caligula thus decides to be destiny, seeking to show his people the one truth he has discovered: that life is inherently absurd. He aims to make them aware of their mortality and sadness by instilling in them his understanding of the absurd, hoping they can live quantitatively and intensely, as he does.

In this way, Camus manages to evoke both sympathy and admiration for Caligula. The Emperor desires to share his profound truth with his people, wanting them to understand for their own good. Caligula believes in making his people aware of the absurd so they can live fully, mirroring his own existential realization. Through his actions and intentions, Caligula becomes a complex figure, simultaneously tragic and heroic, challenging the audience to grapple with the profound implications of his philosophy.

In "le Mythe de Sisyphe," Camus explores the concept of the absurd, highlighting the futility of human existence in the face of inevitable death. He argues that the realization of our mortality and the consequent sense of meaninglessness in our actions do not justify suicide, but rather underscore the value of life. According to Camus, the absurd arises from the conflict between our desire for meaning and the indifferent universe. Despite this, he asserts that we are born free and possess the autonomy to choose our paths, free from metaphysical constraints.

Camus, an atheist, rejects the notion that any predetermined fate dictates our actions. He emphasizes that humans are inherently driven to seek knowledge and truth. Our quest to understand the world and ourselves is intrinsic, but it is an endeavor marked by an eternal gap, as complete comprehension remains elusive. Even in scientific endeavors, this gap persists, preventing any theory from being entirely definitive. The only certainty we have is our mortality. While the awareness of the absurd might lead some to contemplate suicide as a response to life's perceived futility, Camus firmly believes that the quest for knowledge and the ultimate truth of our mortality compel us to continue living. He encourages perseverance, affirming the intrinsic value of life despite its absurdity.

Before we can discuss the situation of French education today and in the recent past we should look at its history as this helps to explain the elitisme in the system.
We need to go back to the late 18th century when Napoleon put forward his views on education. He believed that people should be educated in order for the state to run smoothly. ie: he did not really believe in the right of people to be educated just in the need of the state for people to be educated. As most of the population were involved in agriculture at that time, there was only need for a very basic primary education for the majority of people. This he left mainly up to the church as he believed the church would promote social cooperation. Secondary and Higher education were more important as the would train the professionals which the country needed, and this section of education was therefore run by the state. At this stage we can already see the opportunity for a gap between primary & secondary education which remained in fact until relatively recently, despite attempts at reforms which I will go into later. This system of education did not lead to much social mobility as the children from poorer social backrounds left school after primary, "ecole primaire", with a very basic education, whereas the children from richer backgrounds could go on to secondary and higher education. These "bourgeois" children would then go on to Lycée and either to University or "Les Grandes Ecoles" so joining the class of the élite. This elitism has survived to a certain degree up to today. 
The gap between primary and secondary education became a major concern for the later governments. Under the second and third republics not much advance was made on the education question as this did not appear to be a priority.
Under the forth republic reforms were proposed but because of the multi-party governments who had to face internal struggles all the time, they failed in most cases to be passed.<|end|><|assistant|>

Before we can discuss the situation of French education today and in the recent past, it is essential to look at its history. This historical context helps to explain the elitism that persists in the system. To understand this, we need to go back to the late 18th century when Napoleon put forward his views on education. He believed that people should be educated primarily to ensure the state ran smoothly. He did not see the right to education as an individual entitlement but rather a necessity for state functionality. As most of the population was involved in agriculture at that time, there was only a need for basic primary education for the majority. This responsibility he left mainly to the church, believing it would promote social cooperation. Secondary and higher education, however, were deemed more crucial as they trained the professionals the country needed, and thus this section was run by the state.

At this stage, we can already see the opportunity for a gap between primary and secondary education, a gap that remained until relatively recently, despite attempts at reforms that I will go into later. This system of education did not lead to much social mobility. Children from poorer backgrounds left school after primary education with a very basic education, while children from richer backgrounds could proceed to secondary and higher education. These "bourgeois" children would then go on to Lycée and either to University or "Les Grandes Ecoles," joining the class of the elite. This elitism has survived to a certain degree even today.

The gap between primary and secondary education became a major concern for later governments. Under the second and third republics, not much progress was made on the education question, as it did not appear to be a priority. Under the fourth republic, reforms were proposed, but due to the multi-party governments facing internal struggles all the time, they failed in most cases to be passed.

Studies in demography have shown that the growth of a nation is closely linked to its economic development, social structure, and also cultural trends. On studying France throughout the twentieth century we can see that this is indeed true.
If we start at the beginning of the century we see that the growth of the population was inhibited greatly by the first world war, where France suffered many losses. The fact that the men in the society left to fight meant that the number of births was reduced greatly. This was also the case on the return of the men, when many did not come back having been killed. Therefore after the first world war the population of France decreased greatly.
Immigration was already present at this time, and helped to make up for the large number of losses in the war. Slowly the population began to build itself up again until the beginning of the Second World War. In this war France did not suffer as many casualties and deaths as in the first world war, but the fact that there had already been losses made the situation grave for France. The economy needed rebuilding, as did the whole country, and the work force was very depleated. There was an urgent call for immigrant workers to come to France, and indeed they did come (about 4 million).
When the troops came home, and families were reunited there was a great increase in births. The previous Malthusian attitude that less children meant a better life and greater security was replaced by a new attitude that in order to create and rebuild France a strong workforce was needed. Having a child was regarded as an 'investment in the future'. The french realised that a defeat was due to the fact that they were not a strong nation, and they wanted to build such a nation.
The gouvernement also adopted various policies to try and increase births in the society. It was suggested in the 1920s that contraception should be made illegal, but in the end this was restricted. Family allowances were increased, and medical costs were paid for in order to try and encourage births. Also leave from work was increased.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Studies in demography have shown that the growth of a nation is closely linked to its economic development, social structure, and cultural trends. On studying France throughout the twentieth century, we can see that this is indeed true.

If we start at the beginning of the century, we see that the growth of the population was inhibited greatly by the first World War, where France suffered many losses. The fact that the men in society left to fight meant that the number of births was reduced greatly. This was also the case on the return of the men, when many did not come back having been killed. Therefore, after the first World War, the population of France decreased greatly.

Immigration was already present at this time and helped to make up for the large number of losses in the war. Slowly, the population began to build itself up again until the beginning of the Second World War. In this war, France did not suffer as many casualties and deaths as in the first World War, but the fact that there had already been losses made the situation grave for France. The economy needed rebuilding, as did the whole country, and the workforce was very depleted. There was an urgent call for immigrant workers to come to France, and indeed, they did come (about 4 million).

When the troops came home and families were reunited, there was a great increase in births. The previous Malthusian attitude that fewer children meant a better life and greater security was replaced by a new attitude that in order to create and rebuild France, a strong workforce was needed. Having a child was regarded as an 'investment in the future'. The French realized that defeat was due to the fact that they were not a strong nation and wanted to build such a nation.

The government also adopted various policies to try and increase births in society. It was suggested in the 1920s that contraception should be made illegal, but in the end, this was restricted. Family allowances were increased, and medical costs were paid for to try and encourage births. Additionally, leave from work was increased.

The roots of the problems in higher education lie with Napoleon's policy on education which was to educate a well-trained small elite to run the country, while guaranteeing that the country remained stable by ensuring that the majority of the population was not over-educated. Although any French citizen with the baccaleauréat is entitled through the constitution to a university education, the system is still characterised by major inequalities.
The system of non-selection for all univerisity courses (with a few exceptions such as dentistry and medecine had led to the impoverishment of the quality of instruction and the status of the universities. Trying to appear to be democratic, the system allows any bachelier to enter the first year of a university course. However, the drop out rate is incredibly high, about 57%, so many waste a year and undergo a great deal of stress, both emotional and financial in this manner. Before the Evènements of 1968, many argued that the universities were overcrowded, dirty, and ruled to closely from Paris. After 1968, Edgar Faure tried to allow for more autonomy and less direct rule from Paris. Although the Ministry was still to be responsible for Building costs, the universities were to be allowed to divide into Unités d'Enseignement et de Recherche (UER) and given more freedom in chosing accademic staff. However, universities were often divided into new universities according to the political leanings of its professors, and have been held back by political squabbles. The university graduate does not enjoy the same prestigue as his European counterparts. The Universities have little contact with the outside business world and the divided nature of the UERs allows little scope for cross fertilization of disciplines. A licence, does not automatically guarantee a good job, and a "jeune diplomé" could quite easily find himself working in a supermarket check-out. Many students, therefore wonder if it is worth the strain of the French university which does not guarantee any future. When it comes to the top jobs, the ex-students of the "Grandes Ecoles" will always be top priority. Described by "The Guardian" as "The Cram de la Cream", these schools train an elite for future top careers in administration, industry and government. Two-thirds of the top hundred french firms have directors who are ex graduates of these schools . The roots of the problems in higher education can be traced back to Napoleon's policy on education, designed to educate a well-trained small elite to run the country, while ensuring that the majority of the population remained under-educated to maintain stability. Although the French constitution grants any citizen with a baccalaureate the right to a university education, the system is still characterized by major inequalities.

The system of non-selection for all university courses, except for a few exceptions such as dentistry and medicine, has led to the impoverishment of the quality of instruction and the status of universities. In an attempt to appear democratic, the system allows any bachelier to enter the first year of a university course. However, the dropout rate is incredibly high, about 57%, with many students wasting a year and experiencing significant emotional and financial stress. Before the events of 1968, many argued that the universities were overcrowded, dirty, and heavily influenced by Paris. After 1968, Edgar Faure sought to grant universities more autonomy and reduce direct rule from Paris. Although the Ministry remained responsible for building costs, universities were permitted to divide into Unités d'Enseignement et de Recherche (UER) and gain more freedom in choosing academic staff. Despite these changes, universities were often divided along political lines and became mired in political squabbles. Consequently, the prestige of a university graduate is not as high as that of his European counterparts. Universities have limited contact with the outside business world, and the divided nature of the UERs restricts cross-disciplinary collaboration. A university degree does not automatically guarantee a good job, and many students, including a "jeune diplomé," might find themselves working in a supermarket checkout.

Students often wonder if the strain of the French university, which does not guarantee any future, is worth it. When it comes to top jobs, graduates of the "Grandes Ecoles" are given top priority. Described by "The Guardian" as "The Crame de la Cream," these schools train an elite for future top careers in administration, industry, and government. Two-thirds of the top hundred French firms have directors who are ex-students of these schools, allowing privileged graduates to secure high-ranking careers and accelerated promotions.

In discussing the factors which have marked the development of industrial relations in France under the Fifth Republic, it is first worth mentioning that de Gaulle established the 'comités d'entreprise' in 1946, a forum where the management (patronat), staff and trade unions could meet to discuss the business objectives and solve any disputes between different interest groups. It must also be noted before beginning the discussion of the Fifth Republic, that from 1884-1968 French Unions did not have the right to organise collectively at the workplace, they only had the right to 'social status' - as a national body. Furthermore, the French union movement is not organized according to professions as in Great Britain, but along lines of ideological stance, which gives it a different role altogether. The French unions were not, for a long time, concerned with representing the immediate material interests of their members, but in fighting long-term battles which they hoped would bring about a better and more just society. The CGT (Conféderation Générale du Travail) the largest union with ca 1.2 million members (it claims more) has always had strong communist affiliations, and has constantly been hostile to cooperation with the patronat, seeing its role as the destruction of capitalism. The CFDT (Conféderation française démocratique du travail), has a more reformist stance, and the FO (Force Ouvrière) has a more co-operation nature.
Perhaps due to the ideological extremism of the CGT, perhaps through fear of losing jobs, or of opposing a very authoritative patronat, union membership in France has always been weak, representing at the present time only 15% of the workforce. Thus we begin our discussion of the Fifth Republic.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
In discussing the factors which have marked the development of industrial relations in France under the Fifth Republic, it is first worth mentioning that de Gaulle established the 'comités d'entreprise' in 1946, a forum where the management (patronat), staff, and trade unions could meet to discuss business objectives and resolve disputes between different interest groups. It is also important to note that, from 1884 to 1968, French unions lacked the right to organize collectively at the workplace, possessing only the right to 'social status' as a national body. Unlike British unions, which are organized according to professions, French unions align themselves along ideological stances, thus giving them a distinct role.

For a long time, French unions were not primarily focused on representing the immediate material interests of their members but were engaged in long-term battles aimed at fostering a more just society. The CGT (Confédération générale du travail), the largest union with around 1.2 million members (though it claims more), has consistently held strong communist affiliations and has been steadfastly hostile to cooperation with the patronat, viewing its role as dismantling capitalism. In contrast, the CFDT (Confédération française démocratique du travail) adopts a more reformist stance, while the FO (Force Ouvrière) emphasizes cooperation.

Perhaps due to the ideological extremism of the CGT, or possibly driven by fears of job loss or opposition to a very authoritative patronat, union membership in France has historically been quite weak, representing only 15% of the workforce today. This context sets the stage for our discussion of the Fifth Republic.

When the socialists came to power in 1981, the Trade Unions hoped to gain a lot. In the Auroux laws of 1982/3 the socialists looked to sorting out the "code du travail" whose laws had barely been implemented especially due to the large number of Petite et Moyenne Entreprise which existed. They changed about 1/3 of this "Code du Travail" giving greater protection in the workplace for the worker, rules on disciplinary matters publicised and checked by the Ministry of Labour, and increased freedom of expression. result:
All industrial relations are based on socialist groupings. In France, unionization has proved to be very weak and generally unsuccessful, reflecting the division and instability of the Socialist political parties. When the socialists came to power in 1981, the Trade Unions hoped to gain a lot. In the Auroux laws of 1982/3, the socialists focused on sorting out the "code du travail," whose laws had barely been implemented. They changed about 1/3 of this "Code du Travail," giving greater protection for workers in the workplace, rules on disciplinary matters publicized and checked by the Ministry of Labour, and increased freedom of expression. However, completely against the Trade Unions' wishes, the Socialists made redundancy easier to give and were trying to make the working week more flexible before the 1986 elections.

Trade Unions were legalized in 1884, although they were not allowed to form meetings or have a place on factory floors and public service sites, including railways, were initially forbidden to unionize. However, workers had to wait until November 1968 for trade unions to be given legal status in factories and workplaces. This came after violent and extensive strikes during May 1968 when it is said that approximately 100,000 workers struck, frightening employers into changing attitudes.

The main Trade Union group is the CGT, founded in 1895, which is closely attached to the Communist Party (PCF) and advocates industrial action, with a large number of its members being affiliated with the PCF. The CGT-FO, a breakaway from the Communist CGT in 1947, is another significant group. The third biggest party is the CFDT, formed in 1963 when the CFTC split due to its radical stance becoming unacceptable to many of its Catholic members. The CFDT is connected with the PS (Parti Socialiste) but is the least eager to appear as acting as a back-up for politics.

Besides these three groups, there are many other Trade Union formations in France. Their large number signifies their weakness and low membership.

Although the Fifth Republic has been considerably more stable than previous Republics, there have, however, been various changes in government which have prevented continuity in policy matters, especially in terms of education.
I will briefly mention previous reforms from the beginning of the Fifth Republic and show that the present situation is still beridden by inequality and various forms of social selection at secondary and at higher education level. I will briefly compare it to points in the English system. 
The Fouchet reforms made the first cycle of secondary school (the first four years) more combined, yet they also introduced tracks or 'filières' at this early stage where people had to make options concerning their future. It proved that those from the lower social classes were encouraged, and still are to a certain extent to take the shorter educational option which leads to employment at an earlier stage.
Haby sought to resolve these problems of social selection and aimed to postpone the need to make choices until a later time. He envisaged an orientation cycle in the last two years of the first cycle, then for those carrying on, there was to be a general course of two years when the first half of the 'baccalauréat' would be taken, then the last year would involve more choice for students. The second half of the 'bac' would be taken at this stage. 
The problem was that the orientation cycle brought back some of the 'tracking' of the previous system so a form of social selection still continued.
Savary aimed to reduce these inequalities but a change of government shortened his tenure in office.

Although the Fifth Republic has been considerably more stable than previous Republics, there have, however, been various changes in government which have prevented continuity in policy matters, especially in terms of education. I will briefly mention previous reforms from the beginning of the Fifth Republic and show that the present situation is still beset by inequality and various forms of social selection at secondary and higher education levels. I will briefly compare it to points in the English system.

The Fouchet reforms made the first cycle of secondary school (the first four years) more combined, yet they also introduced tracks or 'filières' at this early stage, where people had to make options concerning their future. It proved that those from the lower social classes were encouraged, and still are to a certain extent, to take the shorter educational option which leads to employment at an earlier stage.

Haby sought to resolve these problems of social selection and aimed to postpone the need to make choices until a later time. He envisioned an orientation cycle in the last two years of the first cycle, then for those carrying on, there was to be a general course of two years when the first half of the 'baccalauréat' would be taken, followed by the last year, which involved more choice for students. The second half of the 'bac' would be taken at this stage. However, the orientation cycle brought back some of the 'tracking' of the previous system, thus continuing a form of social selection.

Savary aimed to reduce these inequalities, but a change of government shortened his tenure in office. Chevènement aimed more at reconstructing than reforming, with the encouragement of an 'école démocratique' as opposed to the idea of 'école unique' by Haby.

The Algeiran crisis led the French Parliament in 1958 to allow de Gaulle and his government recast the political groundrules in a new constitution. This, he confirmed, would be typical of any constitution in a traditionally democratic Western society. Despite this limitation de Gaulle and his followers were able to shape the new Constitution largely according to their own views as to what would constitute a strong and durable republican regime. Debré, for example, was impressed by the British model; parlementarisme rationnel meant that the Government is not at the mercy of Parliament, yet is ultimately answerable to it and thereby be forced to resign.
De Gaulle, however, was the main inspiration of the Constitution. His experience of 1940 made him realise the need for strong, determined leadership from the top. Before the war this was greatly lacking.
The majority of articles relevant to the Presidnet in the 1958 Constitution were largely similar to those under the Third and Fourth Republics. Despite this, there were several new powers introduced and listed in Article 19 including, for example, Article 11 - referendum, Article 12 - right of dissolution and Article 16 - emergency powers.
There were, however ambiguities and certainties in the text which have proved very significant in determining the President's role in the 5th Republic. The role of the Prime Minister was such that he had powers and responsibilities in respect of government policy that could be seen to overlap with the President's function to mediate (arbitrage) between contending groups to ensure the smooth running of the country, assigned to him by Article 5.
This was open to varying interpretation. The maximalist interpretation was generally accepted. This meant that the President, instead of being limited to the 'domaine réservé' ie the powers attributed to him under the Constitution, he was justified by virtue of this article in intervening in policy-making and its implementation.

result:
The Algeiran crisis led the French Parliament in 1958 to allow de Gaulle and his government to recast the political ground rules in a new constitution. He confirmed that this would be typical of any constitution in a traditionally democratic Western society. Despite this limitation, de Gaulle and his followers were able to shape the new constitution largely according to their own views of what would constitute a strong and durable republican regime. Debré, for example, was impressed by the British model; parliamentary rationalism meant that the government was not at the mercy of Parliament but was ultimately answerable to it, thereby being forced to resign when necessary.

De Gaulle, however, was the main inspiration behind the constitution. His experience of 1940 made him realize the need for strong, determined leadership from the top, something that was greatly lacking before the war. This shaped the creation of the new constitution. The majority of articles relevant to the President in the 1958 Constitution were largely similar to those under the Third and Fourth Republics. Despite this, several new powers were introduced and listed in Article 19, including Article 11 (referendum), Article 12 (right of dissolution), and Article 16 (emergency powers).

However, ambiguities and certainties in the text have proved very significant in determining the President's role in the 5th Republic. The role of the Prime Minister was such that he had powers and responsibilities in respect of government policy that could be seen to overlap with the President's function to mediate (arbitrage) between contending groups to ensure the smooth running of the country, assigned to him by Article 5. This was open to varying interpretation. The maximalist interpretation was generally accepted, meaning that the President, instead of being limited to the 'domaine réservé' (the powers attributed to him under the Constitution), was justified by virtue of this article in intervening in policy-making and its implementation.

The President was also independent in carrying out this function: he was not accountable to Parliament by virtue of Article 68 and was not even directly accountable to it via ministers or the Prime Minister. His countersignature was not required by him, which further emphasized his autonomy in governance.

The trade union movement in France originated after the French revolution and has always tended to be revolutionary or ideological in character. The number of French employees unionized is relatively small (about 11%) and thus there is great competition between individual trade unions for membership, and a great distinction between the individual characteristics.
During an economic expansion, as was experienced by France in the period 1945-75, unions can make demands for their workers for better pay and working conditions. But during a recession, as followed the oil crisis in 1975, their demands would be ineffective and membership would drop. This is what happened in France.
Membership fell as the unions were deemed ineffective in securing worker demands. The unions has always been political in nature which limited their membership, and once membership dropped, those members who were left tended to be those who identified with the unions' political views, which restricted union aims still further.
Before 1968, unions were not legally allowed in the workplace in France and there were few negotiations. The little there was was at a general and regional level, far removed from the average worker's demands, and this did not help the falling membership numbers.
Employers tended to be suspicious of unions and did not see them as a valuable means of worker representation. This was because the great majority of firms in France were small family concerns which had sprung up in the 19th century - the PME (petites et moyennes entreprises). The boss was seen as a patriarch who should not be challenged.
The period of industrial relations in France under the 5th Republic can be divided into three periods. The first is 1958 to 1968. During this time the State was highly interventionist in its approach to the economy, regulating pay and price levels and investing in and developping the economy. Employers were wary of unions, so the state had to act as an intermediary between the two sides to develop a little dialogue between them. <|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The trade union movement in France originated after the French revolution and has always tended to be revolutionary or ideological in character. The number of French employees unionized is relatively small (about 11%), leading to intense competition among individual trade unions for membership. This competition, along with significant distinctions between the characteristics of different unions, creates a challenging environment for unions.

During an economic expansion, such as the period experienced by France from 1945 to 1975, unions can make demands for their workers for better pay and working conditions. However, during a recession, as experienced following the oil crisis in 1975, their demands often proved ineffective, leading to a drop in membership. This decline became a reality in France.

Membership fell as unions were deemed ineffective in securing worker demands. Historically, the unions have been political in nature, limiting their membership primarily to those who identified with their political views. This further restricted union aims. Before 1968, unions were not legally allowed in the workplace in France, and only minimal negotiations took place at general and regional levels. This disconnect from the average worker’s demands contributed to declining membership numbers. Employers were often suspicious of unions, viewing them as non-essential, as the majority of firms in France were small, family-owned businesses (petites et moyennes entreprises - PME). The boss was considered a patriarch who should not be challenged.

The period of industrial relations in France under the 5th Republic can be divided into three periods. The first period, from 1958 to 1968, saw the state playing a highly interventionist role in the economy. It regulated pay and price levels and invested in the economy's development. Employers, wary of unions, often found it necessary for the state to act as an intermediary to facilitate some dialogue between the two sides.

result: Under the 5th Republic, the most salient feature that emerged is the form of presidentialism initiated by General de Gaulle and continued by his successors. From 1791 to 1958, France experienced 16 constitutions and 3 Republics since 1875. The 4th Republic was characterized by a weak government and a weak presidency, with power concentrated in the hands of a divided National Assembly. The collapse of the 4th Republic, compounded by the mounting Algerian problem, brought the charismatic figure of de Gaulle back into power, who was seen as the only person capable of solving the crisis. In his years in exile, de Gaulle witnessed France humiliated by its defeat and subsequent occupation by the Germans, ruled by the notorious Vichy regime, and after the war, still not in control of its fate, having to align with the United States. France was referred to as "the sick man of Europe." De Gaulle perceived this sickness as a result of the state's role and authority being undermined. Upon coming to power in 1958, de Gaulle was determined to strengthen the state and create a strong Executive, which he hoped he would lead. His importance in shaping the 1958 constitution cannot be overstated; while it might be said the constitution was tailor-made for him, it is more accurate to consider that the constitution became increasingly tailor-made for him as a result of constitutional amendments and changes in political life. In drafting the constitution, two conflicting notions had to be reconciled. De Gaulle favored a return to the old Bonapartist tradition of the President having almost omnipotent powers, while others feared this concentration of power in one source wanted the government to have more power. A compromise was reached, sharing power between a strong Executive comprising a president and a cabinet headed by a Prime Minister responsible to Parliament. Ultimately, de Gaulle strengthened the Executive in favor of the presidency and his interpretation of the ambiguous word "arbitrage" has remained untouched for over 30 years.

When General de Gaulle came to power in 1958, it was generally expected that the role of president would be given a new status in the policy of decision making. De Gaulle's Bayeux speech and subsequent centrings made it clear that a clearly visible president was required, who would be the 'keystone' to the parliamentary régime. The constitution of 1958 honoured this, by placing the President first among the members of parliament.
There is however a fundamental difference between the powers that the constitution and those who drafted it gave the President and the powers that he subsequently acquired. The result is a very interesting example of how circumstances and personality can change the constitution.
The constitution had originally left policy and decision making to the prime minister and his government (articles 20-23). According to the constitution, the President was only to assume the role of constitutional dictator in times of grave trouble (art. 16). In a brilliant exegis of the constitution he had authored in large part, Michel Debré said that the role of the President was to be that of an arbiter, to oversee the constitution, and be 'beyond politics and the political parties. 
This seems to have been somewhat unrealistic. Neither the war in Algeria, nor, despite appearances the personality of de Gaulle would let him be the arbiter of the constitution.

result:
When General de Gaulle came to power in 1958, it was generally expected that the role of president would be given a new status in the policy of decision-making. De Gaulle's Bayeux speech and subsequent centrings made it clear that a clearly visible president was required, who would be the 'keystone' to the parliamentary régime. The constitution of 1958 honored this by placing the President first among the members of parliament.

There is, however, a fundamental difference between the powers that the constitution and those who drafted it gave the President and the powers that he subsequently acquired. The result is a very interesting example of how circumstances and personality can change the constitution. Initially, the constitution had left policy and decision-making to the prime minister and his government (articles 20-23). The power granted under article twelve to dissolve parliament would, according to Michel Debré, only allow a short exchange with the public. According to the constitution, the President was only to assume the role of constitutional dictator in times of grave trouble (article 16). In a brilliant exegesis of the constitution he had authored in large part, Michel Debré said that the role of the President was to be that of an arbiter, to oversee the constitution, and be 'beyond politics and the political parties.'

This seems to have been somewhat unrealistic. Neither the war in Algeria nor, despite appearances, the personality of de Gaulle would let him be the arbiter of the constitution. The referendum in 1962 gave the President the legitimacy of the public vote, making him directly answerable to the people.

In 1964, Charles de Gaulle realistically defined his role as President. He remained prepared to play the role of arbiter when absolutely necessary. According to him, he was the head of Parliament and no other institution, social or judiciary, was higher than him. He saw Parliament as 'sitting around him.'

The constitution of the 5th Republic was adopted by the nation on the 28th of September 1958. It was a compromise between the Gaullists and other political forces. Although a rather controversial constitution two facts did emerge. First that the presidency had been strengthened and secondly that the executive had been strengthened vis-à-vis the parliament.
I will briefly discuss the Prime Ministers role and then elaborate on the Presidents functions. Then I will analyse each presidency showing how the presidents role has evolved.
In the constitution it is not very clear who exactly is in charge. Some articles clearly suggest it is the prime minister who is in charge while past Presidents and prime ministers have claimed it is the president. Some argued that there should be a twin-headed executive but in the past prime ministers have always accepted Presidential supremacy.
The constitution says that the Prime Minister is in general charge of the government. Certain function have been clearly listed eg. The appointing of ministers. However this function has been usurped by the president, along with certain other functions.
Giscard d'Estaing when asked what the prime minister role was, replied that the prime minister was in charge of contingency problems whereas the president was in charge of what was permanent and essential. He was clearly violating the spirit of the constitution but was merely reiterating what was practiced and preached by his predecessors. So the role of the prime minister remains a controversial issue.
The role of the president is defined in the Constitution but is rather ambiguous and controversial too. Article 5 claims that the president is an "arbiter". This is rather ambiguous. Does this mean he plays a neutral function, as he is an impartial referee and stays away from the making of policies or does it mean he must intervene and play an active role?
The term 'arbiter' is sufficiently vague enough to allow presidents to interpret it as they wish, and this they did. De Gaulle claimed it empowered him to rule the nations and his successors all acted as if it meant playing an interventionist role.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The constitution of the 5th Republic, adopted by the nation on the 28th of September 1958, emerged as a compromise between the Gaullists and other political forces. While it was somewhat controversial, two significant outcomes were evident: the presidency was strengthened, and the executive branch gained more power vis-à-vis the parliament. In this essay, I will briefly discuss the role of the Prime Minister, then elaborate on the President's functions, and subsequently analyze each presidency to demonstrate the evolution of the President's role.

The constitution's delineation of power is somewhat ambiguous. Certain articles imply that the Prime Minister is in charge, while others suggest it is the President. Past Presidents and Prime Ministers have both claimed responsibility, with some arguing for a twin-headed executive, although Prime Ministers have historically accepted Presidential supremacy.

The constitution states that the Prime Minister generally oversees the government, including functions such as appointing ministers. However, this responsibility has largely been taken over by the President, who has also assumed other functions.

When asked about the Prime Minister's role, Giscard d'Estaing asserted that the Prime Minister handles contingency problems, while the President manages what is permanent and essential. This interpretation, while contradicting the spirit of the constitution, reflected the practices of his predecessors, leaving the Prime Minister's role as a still-contested issue.

The President's role, as defined in Article 5 of the Constitution, is equally vague and contentious. The term 'arbiter' is ambiguous; does it mean the President should maintain a neutral, impartial stance, or does it imply an active, interventionist role? The term's ambiguity allowed Presidents to interpret it as they wished, and De Gaulle claimed it granted him the authority to rule the nation. His successors similarly adopted an interventionist approach, reflecting this interpretation.

In summary, the constitution of the 5th Republic was a compromise that strengthened both the presidency and the executive branch. The roles of the Prime Minister and President remain contentious, with the Prime Minister's responsibilities often overshadowed by the President, whose role as an 'arbiter' has been subject to varied interpretations. The ambiguity inherent in the constitution's language has allowed successive Presidents to expand their influence, shaping the evolving nature of the office.

result:
Much of this ambiguity arose from the fact that the Constitution was a compromise between 'presidentialisme' and 'parliamentarism'. The President was given the traditional powers of the Head of State as well as becoming the 'chef cérémoniale de l'Etat', a role similar to that of our Queen, and also becoming the Chief of the army. With articles such as 8, 12, and 11 of the Constitution, the President was granted significant power, as he did not need the 'contreseing' of the Prime Minister or other ministers responsible. The main ambiguity arose with Article 8, which gave the President the power to name the Prime Minister but remained unclear whether he also had the power to dismiss him. De Gaulle capitalized on this ambiguity, appointing Michel Debré in 1958 and effectively withdrawing him from the position in 1962. De Gaulle saw Debré as an effective Prime Minister during wartime, but after the Algerian war, he deemed him no longer useful and effectively removed him from office. In choosing Georges Pompidou to replace Debré, De Gaulle further illustrated that the selection of the Prime Minister was solely his, cementing this interpretation of Article 8 as a cornerstone in the development of presidential power. Choosing Debré initially, De Gaulle set a precedent by creating a 'domaine réservée' for the President, where the Prime Minister would not interfere. The President was to handle long-term issues, particularly foreign and defense policies, while the Prime Minister managed short-term domestic issues. This autocratic and authoritarian role of the President evolved throughout the 5th Republic, with Pompidou, after six years as Prime Minister, continuing to address economic, domestic, and financial policies.

Article 11, in itself, was not so ambiguous. The President could put important decisions to the people by referendum. De Gaulle used it in 1961 to ask the French whether they thought the Algerians should decide their own future. In 1973, Pompidou used it to gauge public opinion on the potential enlargement of the European Community as the British sought to join under Heath. Pompidou also leveraged Article 11 for tactical reasons, to divide the opposition and increase direct contact with the people outside of normal methods.

Demography is the study of population and the effect that its general character has on a country's society and economy. Demographists claim that it is a major factor in considering the problems of that country's evolution - for example, it is thought that many of France's problems during the twentieth century have been caused by a premature decline in the birth rate in the nineteenth century, and the consequent ageing of the population.
At the beginning of the 19th century France had the largest population in Europe, after Russia, and was also a major world power. Since this time, both its power and population in relation to the rest of Europe, have been in steady decline. By the beginning of the first world war, France's population trailed far behind that of Germany, which was one reason why Germany felt confident of victory. During both World Wars France not only lost thousands of men, but the birth rate also dropped dramatically. During the economic crisis and depression between the wars, the birthrate was also low, because it was a time of gloom and pessimism, with little hope for the future, and so people couldn't afford large families.
The consequence of these factors was that by the end of the second world war, the adult population in France was greatly reduced. It was at this time that the birth rate suddenly increased, with the Babyboom. Between 1946 and 1964 the birth rate increased 20%. - this was due to decreasing infant mortality, the introduction of social security and familly benefits, a new optimism for the future, and an abandonning of former Malthusian attitudes, in favour of a more dynamic outlook. The birth rate had in fact, begun to increase before the end of the war, as people took on a care-free attitude, with little feeling of responsibility.
At the same time, the death rate was decreasing, due to advances in medicine, and living conditions. This meant that the number of old people was steadily increasing. So, after the war, there was a reduced number of adults, to look after, and produce goods for, a increased number of children and old people. This, and the need to build the economy, led to the influx of immigrant workers into France, with has in turn led to many of today's problems with immigrants.<|end|><|assistant|>

Demography is the study of population and the effect that its general character has on a country's society and economy. Demographists claim that it is a major factor in considering the problems of a country's evolution. For example, they believe that many of France's problems during the twentieth century have been caused by a premature decline in the birth rate in the nineteenth century, resulting in an ageing population.

At the beginning of the 19th century, France had the largest population in Europe, after Russia, and was also a major world power. Since this time, both its power and population in relation to the rest of Europe have been in steady decline. By the beginning of the first World War, France's population trailed far behind that of Germany. This was one reason why Germany felt confident of victory. During both World Wars, France not only lost thousands of men but also experienced a dramatic drop in the birth rate. The economic crisis and depression between the wars saw low birth rates as well, as people couldn't afford large families in a time of gloom and pessimism.

The consequence of these factors was a significantly reduced adult population by the end of the second World War. At this time, the birth rate suddenly increased, leading to the Babyboom between 1946 and 1964, when the birth rate increased by 20%. This rise was due to decreasing infant mortality, the introduction of social security and family benefits, a newfound optimism for the future, and a departure from former Malthusian attitudes in favor of a more dynamic outlook. Interestingly, the birth rate had begun to increase before the end of the war as people adopted a more carefree attitude, with little sense of responsibility.

Simultaneously, the death rate decreased due to advancements in medicine and improved living conditions. This resulted in an increasing number of elderly people. After the war, there was a reduced number of adults to care for, and produce goods for, an increasing number of children and elderly. To build the economy, France experienced an influx of immigrant workers. This, among other factors, has led to many of today's problems related to immigration.

The French system of higher education has always been of a hierarchical nature and divided. It was so before mai '68, and despite attempts at reform, it has been determined to remain so. Before 1968, French universities were overcrowded (the number of students rose from 122,000 in 1936 to 612,000 in 1968), centralized and impersonal.
In response to the events of '68, the Faure reforms were drawn up. They abolished old universities as such, and gave them the opportunity to form themselves into 'unités d'enseignements et de recherche'. They formed their own councils, and could group themselves into new universities. These universities had their own councils made up of staff, teaching and non-teaching, and student delegates. They elected the President who fulfilled a similar role to that of the British universities' Vice-Chancellor. The Faure reforms gave the universities a framework within which to create a new system of university education and to create new personalities for themselves. These reforms dealt with the centralized and impersonal aspects. But the universities could not cope with their new powers. 
They reverted back to their interdepartmental wrangling, and when it came to joining together to form universities, the subjects dominated by the Left, suchas sociology, did not want to combine with those subjects dominated by more Right-wing professors. The apolitical sciences did not want to be 'contaminated' by the Left-wingers.
Within the new universities, the departments were out to protect their own positions and to protect their share of the global budget, so there was little tendency to create new inter-disciplinary courses as Faure had hoped.
The universities are very much out of touch with the needs of the outside world. Their DEUGs and licences were very much theoretical and literal and of no use in finding jobs in specialized industry. Many professors wanted to keep universities as 'la finalité culturelle'. Donot want interaction with patrons, etc. But this is necessary to make degrees more relevant to job requirements.
Also left wing departments resisted any attempt by State for reform. Refused to see such attempts as sincere or benevolent, always suspected state of ulterior motives. 
Gulf between universities and Grandes Ecoles slightly bridged by Instituts Universitaires de Technologie, but governments leave Grandes Ecoles to themselves as serve France well and were not infected by virus of '68.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The French system of higher education has always been of a hierarchical nature and divided, remaining so before and after the events of '68 despite attempts at reform. Before 1968, French universities were overcrowded, with student numbers rising from 122,000 in 1936 to 612,000 in 1968, centralized and impersonal. In response to the events of '68, the Faure reforms were drawn up, abolishing old universities in favor of 'unités d'enseignements et de recherche', which allowed them to form their own councils and group into new universities. These universities had their own councils made up of staff, teaching and non-teaching, and student delegates, electing a President similar to the British universities' Vice-Chancellor. The Faure reforms provided a framework within which to create a new system of university education and new personalities for themselves, addressing the centralized and impersonal aspects.

However, the universities struggled to cope with their new powers, reverting to interdepartmental wrangling when attempting to join together to form universities. Subjects dominated by the Left, such as sociology, did not want to combine with those dominated by more Right-wing professors, and apolitical sciences resisted being 'contaminated' by Left-wingers. Within the new universities, departments focused on protecting their positions and their share of the global budget, resulting in little tendency to create new interdisciplinary courses as Faure had hoped.

The universities remained very much out of touch with the needs of the outside world. Their DEUGs and licenses were overly theoretical and literal, offering little relevance to specialized industry job requirements. Many professors wanted to maintain universities as 'la finalité culturelle', avoiding interaction with patrons, among other things. Unfortunately, this approach left degrees less relevant to practical job requirements. Additionally, left-wing departments resisted any attempts at reform by the state, viewing them as insincere or motivated by ulterior motives.

The gulf between universities and the more specialized Grandes Ecoles was slightly bridged by Instituts Universitaires de Technologie. However, governments left the Grandes Ecoles to themselves to serve France well, believing that they were not influenced by the '68 virus. This separation perpetuated the hierarchical nature of French higher education, highlighting the ongoing challenges in creating a more cohesive and relevant system.

At the beginning of the Fifth Republic, education reforms had not been implemented because of political instability, other priorities (notably the Second World War) and the notorious French concept of academic tradition and élitism.
The problems to be solved were that of modernization, democratization and secularization. At that time (1959) most children stayed at primary school, only 35% were progressing to secondary education (the sixième year). Berthoin was the first minister of education to address the problem of democratization. He tried to prolong school life for a large number of pupils by making education compulsory until the age of 16, abolishing the entrance examination to the 'sixième' and abandoning the 'classe de la fin des études', where children stayed at primary school until 14. He introduced the concept of orientation and observation, whereby a pupil could be directed towards the school mostly suited to his needs (the prestigious lycée and the College d'Enseignement Général), whilst trying to bring the two schools closer together. The lycée had always been the bastion of élitism, with its Napoleonic tradition.
In 1963 Fouchet created the College d'Enseignement Secondaire, a lower common secondary school, to try and encourage upward social mobility. Jean Capelle, a leading figure in the initiative had very much admired, and tried to emulate the English comprehensive schools. But in an article by Hain Gaziel, his efforts were a failure. The creation of 3 'filières' were basically a division between prospective lycée and C.E.G. students. The third stream was theoretically intended to push pupils to the upper two streams, but in practice transfer was difficult - only 1% managed it. It was dubbed the 'poubelle' of the system. These two reforms came at the time of a population expansion which demanded education of any kind and prevented proper reforms - giving away a little in order to conserve a great deal.
School pupils became disillusioned, seeing the school as an agent of social discrimination. The lycées were for the bourgeois, cadres supérieurs, while the chances of the children of an 'ouvrier' getting anywhere near higher education were remote. It seemed that equality of opportunity and high academic standards were incompatible.<|end|><|assistant|>

At the beginning of the Fifth Republic, education reforms had not been implemented due to political instability, other priorities, notably the Second World War, and the notorious French concept of academic tradition and élitism. The problems to be solved included modernization, democratization, and secularization. At that time, in 1959, most children stayed at primary school, with only 35% progressing to secondary education (the sixième year). Berthoin, the first minister of education to address the problem of democratization, attempted to prolong school life for a larger number of pupils by making education compulsory until the age of 16. He abolished the entrance examination to the 'sixième' and the 'classe de la fin des études', where children stayed at primary school until 14. Berthoin introduced the concept of orientation and observation, allowing pupils to be directed toward the school most suited to their needs (the prestigious lycée and the College d'Enseignement Général), while striving to bring the two schools closer together. Despite these reforms, the lycée remained a bastion of élitism, with its Napoleonic tradition.

In 1963, Fouchet created the College d'Enseignement Secondaire (CES), a lower common secondary school, to encourage upward social mobility. Jean Capelle, a leading figure in this initiative, admired and tried to emulate the English comprehensive schools. However, in an article by Hain Gaziel, his efforts were a failure. The creation of three 'filières' essentially divided prospective lycée and CES students. The third stream was theoretically intended to push pupils to the upper two streams, but in practice, transfer was difficult, with only 1% managing it. The third stream was dubbed the 'poubelle' of the system. These two reforms came at a time of population expansion, which demanded education of any kind and prevented proper reforms, giving away a little to conserve a great deal.

As a result, school pupils became disillusioned, seeing the school as an agent of social discrimination. Lycées were for the bourgeois and cadres supérieurs, while children of 'ouvriers' had remote chances of getting anywhere near higher education. It seemed that equality of opportunity and high academic standards were incompatible.

The Fifth Republic inherited the limitations and dissatisfaction of the Fourth. The education system needed immediate modernisation and democratization. The first reform which aimed at achieve these was the Berthoin reform which was issued by decree under de Gaulle's emergency powers with no opportunity for parliamentary debate.
Under this reform, the school-leaving age was raised to 16, thus ensuring a longer span of education. A cycle of observation of 2 years was introduced for pupils at the age of 11, the idea being that during these 2 years pupils' progress would be observed and at the end of the cycle each pupil would be guided by teachers into either the lycée or the CEG (collège d'enseignement général) as best suited the individual. Berthoin hoped this would reduce social discrimination since all pupils would follow the same syllabus. However, this cycle of observation took place in different institutions - the lycée, the CEG and the primary school - and little transfer of pupils actually took place (1% of pupils transferred to the lycée on average). In these institutions sylabuses were harmonized but this was inefficient and insufficient as far as equality of opportunity was concerned.
The Fouchet reforms of 1963 sought to relieve the continued dissatisfaction of the political Left, primary teachers and trade unions by improving on the Berthoin reforms. Fouchet tried to introduce a common middle school for all pupils - the CES - which would cover the 11 to 14 age span. It was to be formed by converting the junior classes of the lycée into separate units and by transforming the CEG's. At the end of the CES, entry to the lycée would be by the pupils carte scolaire not by exam. Lycée teachers feared a drop in standards, and middle class parents feared tougher competition for their children. Hence conversion was resisted - in the opinion of the Legrand report, the CES never actually came into existance. However the CES such as it was did provide for an increased equality for pupils but the biggest drawback was the streaming system - the 3 filières, of which filière number one had the bad teachers and was dominated by children of the middle class. This led to a continuation of social selection for the lycées and a further setback for democratization.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The Fifth Republic inherited the limitations and dissatisfaction of the Fourth. The education system needed immediate modernisation and democratization. The first reform, known as the Berthoin reform, aimed at achieving these goals. Issued by decree under de Gaulle's emergency powers, it lacked any opportunity for parliamentary debate.

Under this reform, the school-leaving age was raised to 16, thus ensuring a longer span of education. A cycle of observation lasting two years was introduced for pupils at the age of 11. The idea was that during these two years, pupils' progress would be observed, and at the end of the cycle, teachers would guide each pupil into either the lycée or the CEG (collège d'enseignement général) based on their needs. Berthoin hoped this would reduce social discrimination since all pupils would follow the same syllabus. However, this cycle of observation took place in different institutions — the lycée, the CEG, and the primary school — and little transfer of pupils actually occurred, with only an average of 1% transferring to the lycée. While syllabuses were harmonized, this approach was inefficient and insufficient for achieving equality of opportunity.

The Fouchet reforms of 1963 sought to alleviate the continued dissatisfaction of the political Left, primary teachers, and trade unions. Building on the Berthoin reforms, Fouchet aimed to introduce a common middle school for all pupils, the CES, covering the 11 to 14 age span. This school would be formed by converting the junior classes of the lycée into separate units and transforming the CEG's. Entry to the lycée would be determined by the pupils' carte scolaire, not by exam. However, lycée teachers feared a drop in standards, and middle-class parents were concerned about tougher competition for their children. Consequently, the conversion faced resistance, and according to the Legrand report, the CES never came into existence. Nevertheless, the CES provided for increased equality for pupils. Its most significant drawback was the streaming system, which consisted of three filières. Fillerie number one was dominated by children of the middle class and had the worst teachers. This perpetuated social selection for the lycées and further impeded democratization.

Voltaire tackles the question of philosophical optimism in 'Candide' by satirizing the idea that everything occurs for some good. In the novel, the representative of this philosophy is Pangloss, the philosopher employed at Thunder-ten-Tronckh. Throughout the book, Voltaire presents various instances that serve as criticism of l'optimisme. For example, when Candide is forced to join the Bulgar army, he endures severe beatings but remains indifferent, believing it is for his own good. Later in the book, he uses his training to become a soldier and kills two men, a Jew and an Archbishop, without hesitation, and then proceeds to murder his sweetheart's brother. Voltaire demonstrates his disdain for l'optimisme when Pangloss, Candide, and James are caught in a storm at sea, leading to the drowning of James and the destruction of the city they were traveling to. The survivors, including Candide and Pangloss, witness starvation and death. Candide looks to Pangloss for comfort, but the philosopher can only suggest that some good will come of it.

Despite this, Candide remains skeptical of philosophical optimism throughout the story. This skepticism becomes evident when Candide arrives in the New World, South America, and is forced to leave his beloved Cunégonde with the Commissioner of the province. Candide struggles to see any potential good in the situation, especially since his journey to America was motivated by his desire to kill Cunégonde's lovers. As the narrative progresses, we see how Candide is gradually led away from the philosophy of optimism, revealing that the constant belief that good can come from bad is not inspiring but rather a source of continuous disaster. Through Candide's experiences, Voltaire effectively criticizes the concept of philosophical optimism and exposes its flaws.

Philosophical optimism is the target of Voltaire's attack on social attitudes at the time. The idea of divine providence in a world of human cruelty and natural disasters was ridiculous to him, and he tries to hammer the realities home to his reader.
