Philosophical optimism, the target of Voltaire's attack on social attitudes at the time, is rendered ridiculous by the harsh realities Voltaire presents to his reader. He argues that the natural environment, which should theoretically be easily controlled by God, mercilessly hardens on people. To illustrate this, Voltaire has the protagonist, Candide, travel all over the world, witnessing devastating events such as the Lisbon earthquake that claimed thousands of lives needlessly. The sea, too, is portrayed as hostile, as exemplified by the death of Martin during their journey to Portugal. Their trek across the desert from El Dorado results in the majority of Candide's herd of sheep dying from dehydration or quicksand.

Wars result in mass, pointless genocide, as vividly described in the Bulgarian army atrocities in Westphalia. Individual human nature is also portrayed negatively: Candide's Brother is arrogant and patronizing, the sailor on board Candide's ship is ungrateful and grossly insensitive to human suffering, and the police are corruptible and have double standards. Each individual usually exhibits at least one unpleasant side to their personality.

Voltaire's portrayal of nature, civilization, and individual personalities in such an overwhelmingly negative light seeks to demonstrate that it is nearly impossible to find anything that goes "for the best in the world," let alone the belief that everything is for the best. Throughout the book, there is little evidence of good will or the benign influence of God. Instead, the elements conspire in a perverse and malignant way to inflict as much suffering and unhappiness as possible. Certain individuals' misfortunes become almost comic; Pangloss is hanged, dissected alive, flogged, and chained to a Turkish galley. This one-upmanship of misfortune underscores Voltaire's point that the very notion of optimism is utterly absurd.

Pangloss, Candide’s teacher and friend, espouses ‘l’optimisme.’ He is a professed metaphysico-cromonologist, a ludicrous name for a ludicrous subject. Throughout the book, whenever there is a disaster, Pangloss cheerfully proclaims that in the best possible world, everything is for the best! An example of this is when Pangloss explains to Candide how he caught the pox, a terrible venereal disease that can make people sterile and send them mad. Pangloss traces its genealogy and states that originally one of Columbus’s sailors caught it in the New World and brought it to Europe. According to Pangloss, this was a good thing as Columbus also brought back cochineal and chocolate. Without his trip, those items would not have been available, and so having the pox is worthwhile, Pangloss insists.

'Candide' is Voltaire's wittiest work. The target for Voltaire's wit is the theory of eternal optimism, which was promulgated at the time by Leibniz. However, 'Candide' is not just a clever and amusing tale around the 'tout est bien' philosophy but also a critical assessment of the doctrine. Voltaire showed his displeasure with the 'all is for the best' theory in his poem after the Lisbon earthquake, where grieving victims were told that their grief was needed to continue the general scheme of the world. Voltaire mocked them by saying that the masons would probably be celebrating as they would earn a great deal for rebuilding the city, or the heirs to large fortunes would be glad as they would now receive their inheritance. Voltaire described this philosophy as the only possible horror that could be equal to the earthquake itself.

In 'Candide', it is our hero's tutor, Pangloss, who subscribes to Leibniz's theory, even though he sometimes confuses it. We meet the 'tout est bien' principle in the very first chapter, where Pangloss attempts to explain his beliefs with some basic examples, such as ears were given so that spectacles would sit on them properly. Pangloss then expounds on this theory throughout the tale, sometimes with a callous coldness.

This is exemplified when Candide, Pangloss, and Jacques the Anabaptist, Candide's benefactor, are sailing to Lisbon. Jacques is drowned in a shipwreck while saving an ungrateful sailor. The injustice of the situation is clear to all, but Pangloss shows no sympathy and consoles Candide by saying that it had to happen at that time off the coast of Lisbon.

The plot then goes into a ridiculous level. Candide is whipped, and Pangloss is hanged at a magnificent auto-da-fé, which was held so that similar earthquakes would not strike Lisbon again. Candide then begins a series of adventures without his tutor, first with Cacambo and then with Martin, an eternal pessimist.

In the 'Discours sur l'origine de l'inégalité', Rousseau depicts how the development of civilization has corrupted man's natural happiness and freedom by the creation of artificial inequalities of power, wealth, and social privilege.

To discover how this corruption of man came about, Rousseau traces the development of humanity from nascent man to society as it presented itself in the eighteenth century, uncovering the principle sources of human equality.

Natural man, as imagined by Rousseau, was physically strong and thrived in his woodland habitat, was uncomplicated, and had few needs—'la nourriture, une femelle et le repos.' It is essential to Rousseau's argument to see natural man as innocent, independent, and inherently good. When he was alone and depended upon no one, he was equal to his fellow man. However, it was only when man discovered the ability to cooperate with others, to work together, and thus found the basis of civilization, that man's corruption began, leading to social inequalities.

Rousseau places man's development in five separate stages. The first stage is the stage of man's innocence when he is dependent only on himself and in stark contrast to civilized man, he is free from corruption. The second stage is when man forms a social unit in the 'family' as he builds a dwelling and becomes protector and father. This is the 'golden age' from which man is ousted due to the desire for self-improvement. This leads to the development of the concept of property as man, who has become a cultivator, needs to protect the land he has cultivated from others. Consequently, man makes a statement of owning it, leading to a horrible state of war, as Hobbes said, 'of each against all.' The final stage is the establishment of a 'social contract' to secure peace for everyone and to escape the perpetual state of war.

This is the development of man into society from a stage of equality into a life of human inequality.

Rousseau looks at 'man-made-man' and sees how he is dehumanized when compared with earlier man. The social development that occurred when men desired self-improvement led to man being capable of advancement due to science and scientific knowledge. However, as Rousseau stated, 'these supposed improvements were the source of his misfortunes.'

Thoughtless optimism is one of the main themes of Voltaire's 'conte,' 'Candide.' Voltaire sets this optimism in an absurd background, where it is personified by the ridiculous philosopher Pangloss. Pangloss's answer to all occurrences, whether good or bad, is that "all is for the best in the best of all worlds." Despite witnessing human misery and violence, Pangloss continues to quote his philosophy.

Voltaire demonstrates the futility of this attitude in a very amusing and fast-paced way. Pangloss is merely a literary device designed to convey Candide's criticism of thoughtless optimism. Instead of taking it apart and destroying it bit by bit, Voltaire builds up the philosophy of Pangloss to such ridiculous extremes that it cannot possibly be taken seriously.

Voltaire creates a series of great human sufferings brought on both by nature and mankind. In the midst of it all, Pangloss begins his philosophizing that these incidents are good and for the best, making the incongruity of it all particularly striking. For example, when Jacques drowns, Pangloss restrains Candide from jumping in to rescue him by saying that the Earthquake and shipwreck were supposed to happen specifically for the purpose that Jacques might die in Lisbon harbor.

Another example comes earlier in the novel when Candide, having escaped from the Bulgars, meets an old 'tramp' on the road. He soon realizes it is his old master and teacher Pangloss. The Baron's home and family in Westphalia have been destroyed, and Pangloss is ravaged by syphilis contracted from Paquette. Despite this, Pangloss remains optimistic and positive, showing no despair. He merely states that if it were not for syphilis there would be no chocolate in the world. Through the complete absurdity of this comment, Voltaire tackles the problem of thoughtless optimism.

Voltaire is one of France's most famous XVIIIth century philosophers. He has been widely acclaimed as the witty and most perceptive author of the 'roman philosophique.' In Candide, he tells the story of the young hero's travels throughout the world in search of happiness. On his travels, the naïve boy becomes a mature man. Many of the episodes that the characters are put through in the story are outrageous and extravagant. They serve to keep the reader's interest and to provide a cynical commentary on the world through Voltaire's eyes.

The main motivation of the novel, however, was to launch an attack upon a popular philosophical theory of the day: optimism. This doctrine of divine providence carried many prestigious names in its list of followers, such as that of John Locke, a very influential English philosopher of the period. Optimism stated that, as the world was created by God, who is a perfect being, all that happens in it must be for the best. All individual suffering must be attributed to the general good. Voltaire's experiences and knowledge, however, did not allow him to adopt this theory. He had been in Lisbon, for example, when a terrible earthquake destroyed the city and killed an estimated 50,000 people. How could such a terrible disaster possibly be 'for the best,' and how could the deaths of so many people contribute towards the general good?

In the novel, the young Candide accepted Optimism as an unshakeable theory when he was taught it by his tutor, Pangloss, whom he described as the best of all tutors. As the story charts the various disasters experienced by Candide and his companions, the hero finds it increasingly difficult to justify his faith in everything being for the best.

In the 'comte' 'Candide,' we follow the principal character on a journey of discovery filled with strange episodes. Throughout this journey, Voltaire showcases his disdain for the prevailing climate of optimism, often used as an excuse for the lethargy of contemporary society.

The story begins with Candide comfortably installed at the mansion of Baron Thunder-Ten Tronkh, where he is taught the philosophy of optimism by Pangloss, whose maxim is: 'Tout est pour le mieux dans le meilleur des mondes possible.' At the mansion in Westphalia, Candide falls in love with the beautiful Cunégonde. As a result of this love, he is forced to leave the house and wander the world. Despite this upheaval, Candide stubbornly clings to the philosophy Pangloss has taught him, almost to the end of the book. He naively believes that 'Tout est pour le mieux,' even as he encounters numerous experiences that would typically cause someone to abandon such optimism.

For example, Candide is pressganged into joining the army, where he witnesses a bloody battle. Each side claims victory, having caused immense damage, and even the supposed heroes are revealed to be marauding rapists. After surviving this brutal experience, Cunégonde moves on to Holland, where he meets again Pangloss, who is almost dead from the pox. Pangloss maintains his optimism despite his dire condition, and together they journey to Portugal, where they suffer further tragedies. Their friend is killed by a vicious sailor, and they arrive in Lisbon to find it in the midst of a devastating earthquake that claims thousands of lives. Despite these horrors, Candide clings to the belief that such events must be part of some divine plan, though he may be beginning to doubt.

However, Candide's optimism is renewed upon his arrival in South America. The naïve Candide remarks on how the sea and climate are much better here than in Europe, leading him to conclude that this must certainly be 'le meilleur des mondes possibles.'

In particular, Voltaire used the character of Martin to represent pessimism, the belief that humans are inherently evil and that all events inevitably lead to the worst outcomes. Martin revels in destroying Candide's hope and dreams, particularly Candide's longing to reunite with his love, Lady Cunégonde. This hope drives Candide's long and arduous journey, demonstrating Voltaire's argument that the pursuit of ultimate happiness is futile.

Conversely, the character of Pangloss embodies the optimistic theory that "all is best in the best of all possible worlds." As Candide's tutor, Pangloss clings to this doctrine despite enduring immense suffering, including his own public humiliation of being hanged, flogged, and dissected. Voltaire's anger was fueled by recent events, such as the devastating earthquake in Lisbon, where thousands perished. He questioned how such disasters could contribute to the common good, thereby underscoring the absurdity of blind optimism.

Voltaire's narrative also emphasized that suffering is a common experience for all characters, including Candide himself. Candide's unwavering belief in the love of his life, Lady Cunégonde, led him on a journey filled with hope. However, when they finally meet, Candide is deeply disillusioned by her changed appearance and personality, which Voltaire used to illustrate the unattainability of supreme happiness.

Voltaire further attacked the optimistic philosophy by demonstrating that goodness and kindness are often unreciprocated. For instance, Jacques, an Anabaptist considered a good man, saved a sailor from drowning during a storm as they approached Lisbon harbor. However, Jacques himself was swept overboard and drowned, with no one to help him. Even though Candide attempted to save him, it was too late. This narrative element reinforced Voltaire's criticism of the optimistic belief that good inevitably leads to favorable outcomes.

Theology claimed that God took man out of the state of nature soon after his conception, intending him to be unequal. However, Rousseau disagrees, believing in the concept of the 'noble savage.' He posits that all men are born good and equal, and that inequality, as well as vice, only developed as society progressed. In his 'Discours sur l'origine de l'inégalité,' Rousseau explores these ideas further.

Rousseau believed that inequality manifested in two forms: natural or physical inequality and political or moral inequality. Natural inequality, as its name implies, is determined by nature and has always existed, though often unnoticed. It arises from differences in strength, appearance, talents, or gifts, leading to notions of beauty, merit, jealousy, and conflict. These observations of inequality would have been rare in the state of nature, as man rarely met and made no comparisons.

However, as the population grew and men spread further apart, they began to mix more often. This increased interaction led to the development of a sense of moral obligation. When men lived together, their emotional capacity expanded, and differences, or inequalities, began to be noted, starting with sexual inequality due to a sexual division of labor. This marked the beginning of simple society and the development of property laws. As a result, inequality, which existed to a lesser extent in the state of nature, grew with the development of human faculties and was further established and legalized by the introduction of property and eventually laws.

Although inequality already existed, Rousseau describes this period as the 'golden age,' one that could have continued indefinitely without further development. Initially, man was free and happy while independent, but the division of labor and specialization made people interdependent, making labor necessary. This shift led to the invention of agriculture, further specialization, and various jobs being valued differently, resulting in economic inequality. This division of wealth created a stark contrast between the rich and the poor, and further disparities in rank and social esteem emerged. These differences affected the power one held in society, leading to a complex web of inequality.

Candide, written in 1757, is a 'conte philosophique' that describes a metaphysical journey of discovery. Throughout the book, various themes are prevalent, with one of the most dominant being the idea of Optimism. This theme is represented by the philosopher Pangloss, who preaches his philosophy at every turn, even in the face of adversity. Pangloss believes that everything is for the best, including the death of two hundred thousand in the earthquake at Lisbon, which he considers God's will and for the good of mankind. For Pangloss, every cause must have an effect; for example, when Cunégonde drops her handkerchief, it leads to Candide kissing her, thus beginning his path of misery. Pangloss' unwavering philosophical optimism is something that is unobtainable, as the good in the world does not necessarily make up for the bad. Pangloss is a pedant, remaining true to his philosophy without considering anything else.

Throughout the narrative, Voltaire subtly attacks the idea of Optimism, as first put forward by Leibniz in 1721. He accomplishes this by showcasing the illogical travesty of it, which Pangloss parrots throughout the story and exposes through a catalogue of disasters and human suffering, such as rape, pillage, and war. Candide travels and searches for Cunégonde, and in his quest, he tests his understanding of happiness. Initially, Candide follows Pangloss' theory of Optimism, but towards the end, he begins to doubt it. He finally rejects it after meeting the Negro slave in Surinam, left lying naked at the side of the road with an arm and a leg missing, by his master. This encounter represents a turning point for Candide, as he becomes his own judge and rejects the idea of philosophical optimism. However, he is ultimately deceived by appearances, as evidenced by characters like the abbé from Périgod, Paquette, and Giroflée, who seem to embody happiness.

Throughout "Candide," the question of optimism is persistently explored through Candide's recollection of Pangloss's influential words: "Tout est pour le bien dans ce, le meilleur des mondes." This philosophical indoctrination of his childhood leads him to conclude that there is a natural order of 'goodness' regardless of the calamities he encounters. Thrown into the confusion of the Bulgar war and consequently put on trial, he finds himself with a stark choice: either "fusillé" or "fustigé." His unwavering optimism, that everything is for the best under Divine Providence, renders him grateful for the choice.

Even though Pangloss is present in only a few chapters, his optimistic philosophy is constantly ridiculed by Candide's disastrous encounters. Cunégonde is supposedly raped and disembodied, Jaques is killed while a bandit is saved, Candide himself is betrayed, cheated, robbed, and flogged. His childhood "paradis" is increasingly depicted as less glamorous than a horses' stable compared to his adult visions. The daughter of a pope recounts a life history of unspeakable misfortune. Nevertheless, Pangloss insists on reviving Leibniz's philosophy, even as Voltaire mocks: "Je suis toujours de mon premier sentiment, car enfin, je suis philosophe, Leibniz ne pouvant avoir tort."

Despite these challenges, Candide's hope of finding his beloved is continually nurtured. She becomes his reason for all, yet often seems to slip through his fingers. He learns of her infidelity, suffering, and eventually her ugliness and disagreeable nature. Still, he holds on to the belief that everything is for the best, and if ever she agreed to be his wife, it was for the natural order of goodness in the world.

We are experiencing today a definite movement towards an ever closer and more integrated Europe, principally through the creation of the European Communities, including the European Economic Community (EEC), the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), and the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom). The passing of the Single European Act in 1986 has given the concept of an open and common market a new lease of life by adding much detail to existing provisions in the EEC Treaty. Since the Single European Act of 1986, the completion of such an open common market, which is a single market for Europe with no trade barriers, can now be seen as a reality. However, even though Britain has joined the European Communities and accepted its effects through the passing of the European Communities Act in 1972, there has arguably been a very high price paid. This is the loss of absolute supremacy for the English Parliament.

The orthodox theory of parliamentary legislative supremacy states that Parliament cannot restrict its own legislative omnipotence. That is, Parliament today cannot pass laws which limit tomorrow's Parliament's legislative powers, whether these restrictions are on manner and form or on the subject matter, as in the case of the European Communities Act. Inherent in the founding treaties as amended is the idea that European Community law must prevail over national law. Therefore, in the case of a contradiction between the two, European Community law must be abided by. This first aspect of Britain's membership of the European Communities has thus already shown a restriction on Britain's legal system: that of the doctrine of implied repeal. The court's view of this argument is of utmost importance; however, the judges have not had to decide this point yet. The orthodox Lord Denning has described Britain's Accession as a "farewell to our sovereignty" on the one hand, and yet, on the other hand, he has said that theoretically conferred powers can be retained, even though in practice it would be virtually impossible.

The radical theorists would agree that it is indeed a "farewell to our sovereignty" completely. They believe that if Parliament is indeed supreme then it should be able to legislate on absolutely anything, including putting legal limitations on itself.

When the Treaty of Rome was signed in 1957, the foundation was laid for a new "continent"—a united Europe. It was said that Europe would not be created quickly, but over several years. When Britain entered the European Community in 1973 after a national referendum, the debate began concerning Britain's relationship with Europe. The debate flared up again in 1992, when the single European Market was set to be established, raising questions about how far Britain should be integrated. The rest of Europe seemed prepared for 1992, but Britain appeared decidedly hesitant.

The former Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, was not willing to lead Britain into a United Europe because she felt it would result in a loss of sovereignty. There is no doubt that an integrated market would bring multiple benefits for the countries involved. Businesses and other trading organizations are preparing themselves for 1992 and the single market. Trade will be easier, with no frontier controls allowing for the free flow of merchandise. There will be business booms, free competition, and greater freedom to travel.

Many Britons feel that Europe has already affected Britain too much. They cite examples such as decimalization, the introduction of new Euro-passports, and the tying of the pound sterling to the ECU as signs of increasing European influence. They may feel that Britain is being pulled into Europe. Further changes are forecast for Britain, affecting day-to-day matters, and creating a "European Standard." This could make Britons resentful of Europe and weary of "1992 and all that." A single market requires a central institution to coordinate all movements of goods and policies. Will the people of Britain be prepared to relinquish their government and be directed from Strasbourg or Brussels? Many people would not. Will the day come when the pound sterling is taken over by the ECU? It may well happen, but will the Britons have a chance to voice their opinions and views?

Europe may argue that the benefits from a single integrated market would far outweigh any national drawbacks. As the date draws nearer, the awareness of Britons to Europe must increase. They must look into the future and consider the possible effects. Will Britain be drawn into Europe against its will? Perhaps as more of Britain becomes "Eurofied," Britons will wake up and see their sovereignty being taken away. Britain has never geographically been a part of Europe.

European integration is a wide-ranging and controversial subject, concerning the formation of a single political and economic entity among the members of the EEC. Many of the steps toward its completion are already underway. It is unprecedented in the history of Europe. The plans aim to form a single economic market from the member nations, which would undoubtedly and unavoidably lead to political concessions on the part of Britain, potentially resulting in total political capitulation to Brussels. This would inevitably lead to a loss of sovereignty for Britain, as well as for all other member states, meaning a loss of national government power in favor of a central European institution of policymaking. This would cover four main areas of British society: i) economic, ii) political, iii) defense, and iv) legal.

As far as economics is concerned, British independent economic policy would be undermined, primarily because being in a monetary union with other states would lead to the loss of exchange rates as a method for controlling the flow of goods in and out of Britain. The British government would no longer be in a position to devalue or revalue the pound to regain competitiveness with European neighbors. This could result in Britain becoming an unproductive backwater in Europe. Moreover, the Bank of England would lose the right to print and distribute an independent currency, the pound, and the British government would lose control over all monetary policy. This is because a central European bank would have jurisdiction over exchange rates, interest rates, and inflation rates. Consequently, Britain would be left with only fiscal policy to control its economy. There are even rumors that this may be centralized in a new Europe, encompassing everything from tax policy to social security payments.

As a natural consequence of this, there would be a political loss of sovereignty, as British instructions would have no effective power. Already, there is a European Parliament, whose powers are being expanded.

The European Community is a unique grouping of twelve sovereign European Member States who are committed to the development of closer economic and political co-operation. The community has an aim to break down the economic and political barriers that have traditionally divided Europe. In particular, the community seeks to facilitate greater movement within its frontiers; movement not only of goods but of services, capital and people. However, the issue of sovereignty is certainly a much debated one; to what extent should a member hand over its sovereignty to the Community, if at all ? Let us look at the founding of the European Community, before we discuss the issue of sovereignty in more detail.
		There were several attempts at peaceful unification after the First World War, but only after Europe had again been devastated by war was the futility of national rivalry truly apparent. The political and economic exhaustion of the European states called for a fresh start and a far more radical approach to the re-ordering of Europe. This fresh start came about because of three main factors. Firstly, was Europe's realization of her own weakness, after having lost her age-old position at the centre of the world stage to the United States of America and to the Soviet Union. These superpowers were economically, militarally and politically stronger than the divided individual European states. Secondly was the conviction that military conflict should in the future be avoided; after all, the two great wars had both begun as European "civil wars". Thirdly was the common desire for a better, freer world in which international relations would be conducted in a more orderly way. One of the first major moves towards European integration was the creation of the European Economic Community, in 1958. Its membership has grown from the ten original founder countries to twenty-three. One of the most innovative features of the European Community compared with other international bodies is that the member states have ceded to it a part of their national sovereignty and endowed it with its own sovereign powers, which it can use to adopt acts, having the force of national law. This novel approach to pooling national sovereignty is called "integration". The 1970's saw progress in integration, with the introduction of community policy instruments, which enabled greater scope for national policies.<|end|><|assistant|>

One of the first major moves towards European integration was the creation of the European Economic Community in 1958. The Single European Act, signed by the twelve European Community member states in February 1986, represents a commitment by all the member countries to achieve a single market in goods, services and capital before 1992. The Single European Act, signed by the twelve European Community member states in February 1986, represents a commitment by all the member countries to achieve a single market in goods, services, and capital before 1992. Its potential as an organization is vast. With over 312 million inhabitants, it will constitute the largest single market yet to have been created, its gross product being equal to that of the United States and double that of the Soviet Union. As the title implies, one of the greatest stumbling blocks in Britain toward fuller integration with Europe is the belief that it will imply a loss of sovereignty for the elected government. In the course of this essay, we shall attempt to analyze whether this belief is founded in reality and, if it is, why it should cause such fear.

The Single European Act can be analyzed according to three broad areas. Firstly, it reaffirms the Treaty of Rome's original aims— to remove all internal, physical, technical, and fiscal barriers, creating one external frontier with uniform standards and rates within the market. Secondly, it reallocates the powers as they were laid out by the Treaty of Rome, abolishing the right to veto in the Council of Ministers. Thirdly, it recognizes the position of the European Council (not originally included in the treaty), gives the role of foreign policy creation to the European Policy Corporation (EPC), changes the voting procedure for the Council of Ministers, and makes the European Parliament a directly elected body. These significant changes are aimed at facilitating the transition from the partial integration that exists at the moment to fully integrated economic and monetary union.

Britain's reputation in Europe on these issues is not an enviable one. If its image in the foreign press represents any kind of standard, it is seen variously as the most obstructive, bellicose, insular power, thwarting the path of progress, with Margaret Thatcher, the most insular Brit of all, at the helm. Perhaps it is not an unfair image. Although Margaret Thatcher is no longer leading the country, the position of most British politicians on the European issue appears extremely ambiguous. The single European market now seems to be inevitable, although many differing views and interpretations of the idea are still evident. The fact that the concept of a single market is itself very hard to define has been the source of much confusion and some hostility towards it from the British public. A great fear of losing our sovereignty has stemmed from the varying theories of what "1992" entails, and from many people's wish to remain ignorant of current developments.

The most evident implication of the single market is, in my view, the abolition of trade and customs barriers. This will apparently extend our free market economy to the whole of Europe, or at least to those countries who participate. The consequences of the lifting of these barriers can be viewed positively or negatively: for British firms that rely on international trade to survive, the single market will be an incentive to increase dealings with other European firms. Furthermore, it will be more convenient to move goods across frontiers, especially with the imminent launch of the Channel Tunnel for public and commercial use. On the other hand, it can be argued that firms in the British economy will suffer from European competition, or even dominance. If a single European currency is ever introduced as part of the process, it is thought that European firms will have a new incentive to "buy British," as the formalities required in foreign exchange will no longer exist, and the UK's current balance of payments situation may even improve as a result. Similarly, British firms might look for new products in other countries if they are no longer constrained by tariffs, bringing more diversity to their product range and therefore enhancing profitability.

However, the question of the single currency is itself a subject of much controversy. I believe that it is an aspect which is more threatening to British sovereignty than the general concept of the single market. Somehow, the prospect of treating Europe as one market is more acceptable if the countries participating keep their individual currencies and hence their identities. However, the idea of all the states using one currency is generally regarded as being a much greater threat to sovereignty, and would mean, to many people, the sacrificing of the pound to suit the aims of the Europeans.

Everyone eagerly anticipates the arrival of 1992 and the introduction of the single market for the European Economic Community. This significant event will see the expansion of the British market into all other European markets and vice versa. Consequently, the removal of all tariff barriers and customs will enable the free movement of goods, services, people, and capital across Europe.

Despite the apparent advantages, Britain remains apprehensive. As an island nation, the British are not formally connected to the Continent, and there is a lingering sense of British nationalism. The nation may find it challenging to accept orders from a governing power on the Continent, which still seems like a separate entity.

The most obvious advantage of the single market is the much larger market accessible to British industry and the potential for a bigger jobs market. However, one group will face difficulties. Firms that have traditionally relied on importing goods for Britain will be affected by the introduction of the European Currency Unit (ECU). The ECU, a planned single currency within Europe, will simplify purchasing imported components. If successful, firms can buy goods with the ECU without incurring import taxes or using their own currency. Many British people, however, resent the introduction of the ECU, fearing that adopting it would be akin to losing a part of Britain's identity. This reluctance to embrace the future plans, despite their potential benefits, contributes to the slow pace of British public education on these matters.

With the merger of individual markets, the need for extensive paperwork will diminish, as there will be no more exchange controls and redundant bureau de change services. Customs control will also be streamlined, leading to a reduction in staffing.

Another concerning aspect is the proposed legislation. Suggestions have been made to adopt a central legislative power for Europe. This idea is not widely accepted by the British public, as it would mean relinquishing their unique systems of legislation. Many Britons fear that this centralization would result in the loss of their national identity.

In summary, while the single market promises numerous benefits, concerns about identity and sovereignty remain significant obstacles for Britain as it navigates this transformative period.

With 1992 looming ever closer, the debate concerning the sovereignty of Britain is becoming more acute. There are those who feel that Britain should join Europe and enter into "The Single Market." However, on the other hand, there are those who believe that Britain's sovereignty is far too important to abandon. We must now consider the pros and cons of Britain joining "The Single Market."

In general, we are already closely linked with the rest of Europe. Some believe that the only thing that separates us is the Channel. Soon, of course, this will become even less of a barrier with the completion of the "Channel Tunnel." When this tunnel, which will run under the water between England and France, is finally completed (hopefully in the near future), it will be much easier to travel to and from Europe. This is merely one step towards "The Single Market." There are also plans concerning the reduction of trade barriers.

Some people intend to drop all the barriers where trade and commerce are concerned. In this respect, it would become much easier to obtain items from Paris or Rome, and a lot quicker. Imports and exports will also become more frequent and popular. We will be able to sell our goods from Britain to a wider range of customers in several more countries, just as we will also have the ability to buy more goods from a wider background. Buying and selling will become very important in "The Single Market," and business will flourish as a result.

Additionally, there are proposals at present to introduce one monetary system into Europe, including Britain. If this becomes the case, it is believed that buying and selling, as well as traveling, will become less difficult. The introduction of one monetary system would certainly ensure that the majority of problems concerning worldwide money comparisons would almost be abandoned.

However, there are, of course, those who object to this one monetary system, such as Margaret Thatcher. This highlights the concerns that some people have about the potential loss of sovereignty and the importance they place on maintaining Britain's independence.

A very important characteristic of the UK constitution, and one which is central to the question of sovereignty, is that it is the Westminster Parliament that is the supreme legal authority in the UK. According to the orthodox school, which subscribes to the views of Albert Venn Dicey, the Westminster Parliament is omnipotent and can pass laws on any subject it likes to regulate the activities of any person, anywhere, even those of aliens outside British territory. In theory, then, the Westminster Parliament could pass a law banning smoking on the streets of Paris. If our Parliament did so, British courts would be obliged to accept Parliament's decision and pass judgement accordingly. However, in practice, as the Radical school points out, in this hypothetical situation, the Parisiens would take no notice whatever of the UK Parliament's legislation, and Parliament would in effect be fettered.

Dicey said that as each Parliament is omnipotent, and therefore has the power to make or unmake any law, no Parliament could bind its successors as to the content or manner and form of subsequent legislation. The Radical school highlights that since the passing of the European Communities Act in 1972, the Westminster Parliament has ceded its sovereignty and supremacy to Europe. The orthodox school retorts by pointing out that since a Westminster Parliament passed the 1972 Act and put the UK into the European Communities, a future Parliament could just as easily repeal this Act and take us out of Europe again, thereby retaining British sovereignty and Parliamentary supremacy.

Firstly, what is the European Union? It has two distinct forms that concern the British public most: Political Union, followed by Economic and Monetary Union. These issues have become so heated in Great Britain that they have led to numerous disputes within the present government and are considered one of the major reasons for the resignation of Mrs. Thatcher. In losing her, have we not already lost a part of our sovereignty? Europe is forcing change upon us as we have been attempting to stand back, "not letting socialism in by the back door," rather than playing an important role in positively affecting the decision-making processes or in the European Community. Great Britain cannot afford to play a minor role in a two-speed Europe, especially during a recession. This disparity has manifested itself in top governmental disputes, making a loss of sovereignty seem inevitable, whether we like it or not.

On monetary and economic Union, I don't feel that we have much to lose; in fact, I think we would benefit enormously, especially considering the developments in 1992. If only these issues were presented in a more positive light, perhaps with some modifications, I am sure that the British public would agree. After all, how long is it since we lost our sovereignty to the follies of the international stock exchanges in New York, Tokyo, and Frankfurt? Will losing our sovereignty to Brussels or the Bundesbank make much difference? Did not the "Big Bang" in October 1987 send shock waves worldwide with share prices plummeting? World processes are continuously becoming more interconnected, with effects often transcending physical borders. I therefore see European unity as a natural process in world development, something that should be facilitated rather than hindered. Can we really afford to waste time by dragging our feet?

The issue of Political Union is still more disputed. Yes, we have a Queen, but what would happen to her if she were forced to abdicate and be succeeded by King Jacques Delors? This is a very typical misinformed and ignorant statement posed by certain British "patriots."

If the states of Europe were to be unified, Britain would have to accept the loss of its sovereignty. It would be impossible for her to retain all that she has built over the last few centuries. It would be tempting to think of the various European Communities as an embryonic United States of Europe ; especially when we hear politicians talk of the importance of European Unity. However it is important to realise that Europe is a very long way from becoming anything like the United States. When the original 13 American states resolved to form what is now the United States of America, they were intent on forming a political as well as economic entity. They were prepared to yield as much of their own sovereignty as would be essential to allow the newly formed national government to operate as a single international political force. A balance was therefore struck in the constitution to allow the individual states as much self-government as possible while ensuring that, for example in military matters, the central government spoke for all. It is true that today one still hears the old dispute over state sovereignty and attempts to return some power to the individual states, but no-one would challenge the fact that, on matters external to the United States, the government in Washington represents the sole policy-making body.
		In Europe it is quite clear that many people would like to see a political union of the countries since this would produce a formidable international military force. However it is equally clear that while there might be some unified political action flowing from the European Communities (such as was seen over Europe's response to the British involvement in the Falkland Islands dispute), the Communities were intended as purely economic entities in the first place. Membership almost certainly involves some loss of national sovereignty, but the United Kingdom could probably leave the community by a simple majority vote in the Westminster Parliament, something which no state in the United States could lawfully do. We are still a very long way from a Single Parliament for Western Europe with power to make political decisions for all ; and even with 1992 approaching and a single market the gulf between the UK and Europe is very wide.
		The supremacy of Parliament will never be challanged. Its ability to make and break any law - made by it or Europe - means that it retains full sovereignty. Even if today it made laws to that would unite it fully with Europe and relinquish its sovereignty for ever, it could tomorrow repeal all those laws.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
It would be tempting to think of the various European Communities as an embryonic United States of Europe, especially when politicians emphasize the importance of European Unity. However, it is important to realize that Europe is a very long way from becoming anything like the United States. When the original 13 American states resolved to form what is now the United States of America, they were intent on forming a political as well as economic entity. They were prepared to yield as much of their own sovereignty as would be essential to allow the newly formed national government to operate as a single international political force. A balance was therefore struck in the constitution to allow the individual states as much self-government as possible while ensuring that, for example, in military matters, the central government spoke for all. Today, one still hears the old dispute over state sovereignty and attempts to return some power to the individual states, but no one would challenge the fact that, on matters external to the United States, the government in Washington represents the sole policy-making body.

In Europe, it is quite clear that many people would like to see a political union of the countries, which would produce a formidable international military force. However, it is equally clear that while there might be some unified political action flowing from the European Communities, such as was seen over Europe's response to the British involvement in the Falkland Islands dispute, the Communities were intended as purely economic entities in the first place. Membership almost certainly involves some loss of national sovereignty, but the United Kingdom could probably leave the community by a simple majority vote in the Westminster Parliament—something which no state in the United States could lawfully do. We are still a very long way from a Single Parliament for Western Europe with power to make political decisions for all, and even with 1992 approaching and a single market, the gulf between the UK and Europe remains very wide.

The supremacy of Parliament will never be challenged. Its ability to make and break any law—made by it or Europe—means that it retains full sovereignty. Even if today it made laws to that would unite it fully with Europe and relinquish its sovereignty forever, it could tomorrow repeal all those laws. The delicate balance between sovereignty and unity is a defining challenge for European integration, one that echoes the historical complexities of American federalism but on a very different scale and context.

Naturally, the problems of a single Europe would run as deeply as the benefits that we would presumably ultimately receive. It seems to me that for the past few centuries, Britain has always considered itself to be detached from the rest of Europe. Whenever necessary, she has allied herself to European powers, such as in times of war of extreme distrust.

Britain has been eager to maintain a secure balance of power on the continent, but throughout history, she has been more concerned with her overseas empires than with anything else. In the latter half-century though, her empire has diminished and she has had to face mounting responsibility in Europe. Because of her history of isolated sovereignty, it is difficult to accept being a part of a single Europe.

For instance, British law is based largely upon precedent, that is judge-made law. We have established a system of law which dates back many centuries and which is widely known and respected. There is very little European influence on our law, of course, in many respects it will be the same, but the lack of influence will display many differences. With the creation of a single Europe, new law will have to be accepted throughout the continent, and it will cause both confusion and conflict.

The British tend to be very proud and possessive of the law, and changes may well cause ill feelings and discontent. Of course, the same points will apply to the monetary system in Europe. Will there just be one system? The country typically is against major change, and something as fundamental as money would cause problems if it were to be altered. Our individual monetary system, I suppose, could be seen as a symbol of sovereignty.

It can be said that if a single Europe were created, problems may arise over its fundamental political concepts. Of course, Britain would lose its sovereignty, as would the other nations of the union. It has been suggested that the Single Union could be based on a basic federal structure, whereby local autonomy could be saved, but the union as a whole could work together in a democratic manner. To a certain extent, even if sovereignty were lost, some national personality would be preserved. The fact is that, when united, European unity would still essentially be divided.

prompt:
<|user|>Please revise the following essay to improve sentence transitions and flow. Do not add new content or examples—only improve how existing ideas are connected and expressed. Provide only the final essay.

The Crown has power to enter into Treaties which bind the UK in International Law. But this prerogative power does not include the power to alter the rights of individuals within the UK. If alterations to British law are required by the Treaty, an Act of Parliament must be passed. If Parliament fails to pass any legislation required by a Treaty then it may be in breach of its international obligations as imposed by that Treaty. This represents a loss of sovereignty as Parliament is bound to a certain extent in that Parliament is obliged to legislate under the constraint that if does not the UK will be in breach of its international obligations.
		Parliament's freedom to legislate is not in theory fettered by such a Treaty. An Act of Parliament is enforceable by British courts even if it is in breach of Britain's treaty obligations. However in interpreting statutes the court will wherever possible interpret so as to conform with international law.
		The EEC however is a distinctive Community compared with other international organisations in that it has its own broad executive and legislative powers and judicial powers for creating and enforcing Community Law, for example Regulations made by the Council of Ministers, which are directly applicable in all member states. In 1963 the European Court of Justice stated that "... the Community constitutes a new legal order of international law, for the benefit of which the states have limited their sovereign rights, albeit within limited fields, and the subjects of which comprise not only member states but also their nationals". The whole point of Community law is that it should not be overridden by domestic legal provisions of the member states.
		The Community legal order is thus inconsistent with the orthodox view of the doctrine of Parliamentary supremacy and sovereignty.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The Crown has power to enter into Treaties which bind the UK in International Law. However, this prerogative power does not include the power to alter the rights of individuals within the UK. If alterations to British law are required by the Treaty, an Act of Parliament must be passed. Should Parliament fail to pass any legislation required by a Treaty, it may be in breach of its international obligations as imposed by that Treaty. This represents a loss of sovereignty, as Parliament is bound to legislate to avoid breaching international obligations.

Parliament's freedom to legislate is not theoretically fettered by such a Treaty. An Act of Parliament is enforceable by British courts, even if it is in breach of Britain's treaty obligations. However, in interpreting statutes, courts will wherever possible interpret so as to conform with international law.

The EEC, however, is a distinctive Community compared with other international organizations. It has its own broad executive and legislative powers and judicial powers for creating and enforcing Community Law, such as Regulations made by the Council of Ministers, which are directly applicable in all member states. In 1963, the European Court of Justice stated that "...the Community constitutes a new legal order of international law, for the benefit of which the states have limited their sovereign rights, albeit within limited fields, and the subjects of which comprise not only member states but also their nationals." The whole point of Community law is that it should not be overridden by domestic legal provisions of the member states.

Thus, the Community legal order is inconsistent with the orthodox view of the doctrine of Parliamentary supremacy and sovereignty.

Due to the European Communities Act 1972, the United Kingdom has since been subject to community law which, as specified in the original treaty, is supreme over all other domestic law of all the member states.
		Therefore, by being a signature to the 1972 Act and to the preceeding Treaty of Rome, we have relinquished the legislative supremacy of our Parliament, which means that hitherto the European Communities Act, no other organ existed with the power to create or repeal legislation, but which is now no longer the case.
		This surrendering of sovereignty is of course only partial but results in the United Kingdom (I use this term to include England, Wales , Scotland and Northern Ireland, which constitutes the state of the United Kingdom, which is in question, rather than Great Britain which includes only England, Wales and Scotland;) no longer being known as a full sovereignty in the international sense indicating complete independence and freedom from external control.
		It follows that, if in a UK court of law a conflict between two laws occurs, ie, a ruling of the European Community and, a domestic ruling, then naturally the European Community law should take precedence. In practice, judges attempt to reconcile the two opposing laws or follow the European Community law.
		If this did not happen then the UK would be in breach of the Treaty of Rome and would consequently be in breach of international law which would attract international responsibility.
		Incidentally, the Treaty of Rome is particular in that it is directly applicable to the UK. When it was signed no Act of Parliament had to be made to transfer it to domestic law to make it applicable to UK law.
		Membership of the single market obviously has some advantages for the UK. The single European Act of July 1987 was passed through Parliament by the Prime Minister - formerly Mrs. Thatcher - because of the single European Market provision (beneficial to trade for the UK).
		 Unfortunately it also contained other clauses which were overlooked and which have now seriously affected the sovereignty of the United Kingdom.
		Before 1987, the council of Ministers could impose directly applicable law upon the UK which is enforceable in all UK courts, which effectively serves to erode our sovereignty, fortunately, no law could be passed without the UK's agreement as a unanimous decision in the Council was required.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Due to the European Communities Act 1972, the United Kingdom has been subject to community law, which, as specified in the original treaty, holds supremacy over all other domestic law of all member states. By signing the 1972 Act and the preceding Treaty of Rome, we have relinquished the legislative supremacy of our Parliament. Historically, this meant that no other organ had the power to create or repeal legislation, but this is no longer the case. This surrendering of sovereignty is, of course, only partial, resulting in the United Kingdom (which includes England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, collectively referred to as the state of the United Kingdom) no longer being recognized as a full sovereignty in the international sense, indicating complete independence and freedom from external control.

It follows that, if a conflict between two laws occurs in a UK court of law—such as a ruling of the European Community versus a domestic ruling—then naturally, the European Community law should take precedence. In practice, judges attempt to reconcile the two opposing laws or follow the European Community law. Failure to do so would mean the UK is in breach of the Treaty of Rome and, consequently, international law, attracting international responsibility.

Interestingly, the Treaty of Rome is particularly notable because it is directly applicable to the UK. When it was signed, no Act of Parliament was required to transfer it to domestic law for it to be applicable to UK law.

Membership of the single market undoubtedly has some advantages for the UK. The single European Act of July 1987, passed through Parliament by the Prime Minister—formerly Mrs. Thatcher—was largely due to the single European Market provision, which was beneficial for trade. Unfortunately, it also contained other clauses that were overlooked and which have now seriously affected the sovereignty of the United Kingdom.

Before 1987, the Council of Ministers could impose directly applicable law upon the UK, enforceable in all UK courts, effectively serving to erode our sovereignty. Fortunately, any law could not be passed without the UK's agreement, requiring a unanimous decision in the Council. This safeguard has been compromised, impacting the nation's sovereignty.

<|user|>Please revise the following essay to improve sentence transitions and flow. Do not add new content or examples—only improve how existing ideas are connected and expressed. Provide only the final essay.

The Single European Act, signed in February 1986 by the Heads of Government of the 12 Member States of the European Community and which came into force on 1st July, 1987 aims to create a single market by the end of the year 1992. This major target is to be attained by the removal of all fiscal, technical and physical barriers. This means that a merchant or tradesman would be able to sell his goods in any community country, an individual would be able to borrow and deposit money in the banks of any member state and also work in any member state with national qualifications. There would also be the introduction of a European passport and an integrated transport system.

The Single European Act, signed in February 1986 by the Heads of Government of the 12 Member States of the European Community, aimed to create a single market by the end of 1992. By removing fiscal, technical, and physical barriers, this act enabled merchants and tradesmen to sell their goods across any community country, individuals to borrow and deposit money in any member state's banks, and work in any member state with national qualifications. Additionally, the introduction of a European passport and an integrated transport system would further facilitate mobility and commerce within the community. Despite these ambitious goals, the proposal, spearheaded by an Englishman, Lord Coe, faced widespread dissatisfaction in Britain. This dissatisfaction was evident through frequent discussions in Parliament and letters to leading national newspapers, contrasting with Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, who viewed the measures as a compromise.

In accordance with the Constitutional Law of Britain, Parliament is the supreme law-making body, presenting a challenge to the emergence of a supra-national source of law. With Parliament's prerogative power to make treaties, these treaties are not directly effective on British individuals. Consequently, individuals cannot rely on treaties until they are substantially incorporated into UK law by an Act of Parliament, acting as a curb to the enforcement of European Community Law and retaining a degree of sovereignty. However, this perceived advantage is mitigated by a general judicial presumption that Parliament does not intend to legislate contrary to European Community Law.

Personally, I believe that while the integration of Britain into Europe will be beneficial in numerous areas such as freedom of transportation, movement, and work, there are also significant disadvantages. One of the most prominent is the partial loss of sovereignty, which raises concerns about the long-term implications of such integration.

"But we'll lose our sovereignty!" is the cry of the opponents of European unity not only in Britain but throughout the 12 member states of the EC. On this island at the very edge of Europe, however, we do have a particularly low reputation for fighting change and for general xenophobia. What are we afraid of?

Perhaps the most unpopular EC policy in this country is the Common Agricultural Policy Regulations, which dictate the amount of food we are allowed to produce. These policies have been portrayed on television as farmers forced to slaughter their livestock because of low quotas and large amounts of milk going off as farmers are not allowed to sell it. If you mention the common agricultural policy to an Englishman, most will immediately think of the butter mountains, wine lakes, and surpluses of meat. While the positive elements of the policy do not get as much publicity as the negative ones, this portrayal contributes to the perception of the EC as an institution that interferes with and disrupts the British economy and way of life rather than enhancing it.

The idea of "sovereignty" is an old-established term in the world of international relations and is generally accepted to mean that while other states may have a right to have some say in a way that a state runs its foreign affairs, the domestic affairs of that state are the concern of that state alone, and no other state should interfere. While the military interpretation of sovereignty is not as relevant in the context of this argument, it is the perception that the EC is interfering in the economic affairs of each country that causes so much discontent. Political sovereignty seems only to be important to the general public in as much as it involves control of the economy. The reasoning of the opponents of European unity is that the "Brussels bureaucrats" when making policy decisions will have more their interests at heart than those of any particular country.

This is the short-sighted view. The broader and more long-term European citizen will move towards the tendency in the world economy towards global integration.

As there is no written, or codified constitution in the U.K., which has a higher status than that of ordinary law, Parliament can theoretically make or unmake any law whatsoever. In the words of the known jurist Dicey, the premise is that Parliament can bind itself, making the traditional approach orthodox, it is impossible to bind subsequent governments as to the procedure or manner and form of legislation, making entrenchment of statute impossible.

If one considers whether, by adopting this Act, the United Kingdom has lost some sovereignty or "loaned" it, it would be possible to predict the effect subsequent legislation pertaining to the formation of "a single Europe" would have on the sovereignty of this country.

This new order essentially limits Parliament's legislative supremacy, thereby indicating a shift in sovereignty.

As a British student of modern languages, having lived and worked in Paris for a year, and become acquainted with the  French culture, I might be expected to have a more "European" perspective than the average British person. As a British student of modern languages who lived and worked in Paris for a year, I might be expected to have a more "European" perspective than the average British person. Yet if my experience taught me anything, it is that issues of national identity are very emotionally charged. At a conscious level, I support the idea of a united Europe; yet surprisingly often during my year in France, I found myself embroiled in heated debates over the Channel Tunnel and the impact of the 1992 European developments. I frequently surprised myself by the vehemence of my defense of "other" British people who were nervous about the whole prospect.

More than other European nations, I believe the British have a particular attachment to the idea of the nation being sovereign over itself. The French, for example, already seem to mistrust even power at a national level, perhaps a legacy from the French Revolution's ideals. Other European nations are divided into smaller federal regions, as is the case in Switzerland. In fact, Britain has been one of the few European countries not to favor an electoral system of proportional representation. This implies that the British prefer the idea of a single government, united in policy, reflecting the interests of a supposedly united nation. Of course, such a vision is a false one. Nevertheless, such an image makes any loss of sovereignty to such a nation more keenly felt. The current and recent British governments have been at odds with the more common political stance in Europe, with the British one being right-wing and individualistic. In particular, Margaret Thatcher and Nicolas Ridley (rather tactlessly, in his case) opposed a complete alignment with Europe. However, I believe this difference in political stance is a less important factor in the British unease about 1992 than is the more deeply rooted notion of Britain's being self-contained.

In just one year, the original aims of the 1957 Treaty of Rome will be fulfilled, cementing European unity. This will undoubtedly have economic benefits, freeing both trade and the movement of people across boundaries. But perhaps the most significant change is that decisions—over laws, human rights policy, and defense issues—will be taken collectively, not individually. This shift will fundamentally alter the way we understand national sovereignty and identity.

The mentality of the British is deeply rooted in that of an Island race. Ever since 1066, the last time any foreign people successfully conquered British soil, the English—and later, the "British"—have always been the conquerors. In the early Middle Ages, around the times of Edward I, II, and III, English Kings ruled large areas of France. Later in history, during the reign of Queen Victoria, the British Empire came into existence. With the granting of independence to the colonies, Britain was restricting her sovereignty, necessitating special Acts to enable this, but Britain has always retained absolute sovereignty over its own destiny. We have always been our own people, never accepting any higher power (notably, we broke away from the power of the Catholic Church and the authority of Rome in Tudor times). However, now we face the "threat" or "opportunity" of Europe—the actuality of being an integral part of a greater "being," part of a Single Europe with its many advantages and disadvantages, such as the potential loss of sovereign power.

As can be shown by the development of many, if not most, individual states, much greater things can be achieved if small communities are brought together to pool their common resources and form a single sovereign state with common aims, targets, and by necessity, laws. Economically, working collectively is the best way to achieve the highest productivity. Different countries achieve this in varying ways, ranging from a highly centralized state system to a confederal system where only certain decisions are made by the central body. Each constituent community retains varying degrees of power under the differing systems. A "Single Europe" could follow any of these patterns, although so far it is headed towards a relatively loose form of confederacy and is most likely to remain that way.

If the Communities of Europe are to achieve the highest productivity and harmonization, the cooperation and coordination required are essential.

The moves towards a single Europe have many far-reaching political, economic, and social consequences for the Member States. The diversity of the cultures, languages, and political structures present in these nations means that unification will lead to complex problems on both national and international levels. One of the most contentious issues is the pace at which reforms should be initiated and carried out. There is a conflict between federalist nations like Germany and those who wish for a more loosely structured Europe and slower reforms, which seems to be the view of our present government in Britain.

The fears of European federalism expressed by many of our leading politicians and legal figures stem from the idea that the sovereignty of our Parliament is paramount. This view of legislative supremacy was articulated by Dicey, who wrote that "quote...". Problems arose when Britain joined the European Communities in 1972. By this Act, Britain was argued to have limited its legislative competence in certain fields, having ceded its sovereignty to Community Institutions. However, the doctrine of parliamentary legislative supremacy meant that the British Courts were under a duty to apply the legislation made by the British Parliament. This has led to two interpretations of Community Law, with the European Court of Justice consistently ruling that Community legislation must be applied uniformly throughout the member states.

However, the argument extends beyond these doctrinal questions. Many people are concerned about the lack of democratic control over the Community decision-making process and the voting systems used to enact legislation. Another problem is the intention of the Community organs to strengthen the economic and social cohesion of its Member States with a view to promoting the development of Europe as a whole, and in particular reducing disparities between the various states, such as those with the weakest economies, for example Italy. The question of a single Europe and whether this implies a loss of sovereignty for Britain has been one of considerable debate for some time. Last November, one of the principle reasons underlying Mrs. Thatcher's resignation was her negative stance against increasing involvement in Europe. Her view was not shared by many of her party colleagues, who, on the contrary, were conscious of an all too pressing need for Britain to play an active role in a united Europe.

January 1993 is expected to witness the creation of the single European Market. The aims of such a union are essentially economic. All trade barriers will be broken down to encourage and promote free trade between the countries of Europe, in the belief that increased cooperation will lead to increased productivity. In order to facilitate trade between the different nations, many people are in favor of adopting a common currency, namely the ECU. This in turn would also have to lead to the formation of a central European bank.

A single Europe, whilst primarily being created as an economic union, will necessarily have implications on a political level. The European Parliament already exists, but many people envision that in a single Europe, it will play a more important role, with its power potentially surpassing those exercised by individual national governments in Europe and overriding decisions made by them.

For supporters of a single Europe, the question of whether it will entail a loss of British sovereignty is not a primary issue. They argue first and foremost that Britain cannot afford to go it alone and that it is in her interests to join forces with the rest of Europe.

Critics of European union, on the other hand, are afraid that increased cooperation in both the economic and political spheres will give rise to a European superpower which will undermine the sovereignty of Britain in these fields.

Personally, I am in favor of a single Europe, believing that Britain can no longer afford to stand alone in opposition to the other countries in Europe, all of which have long been in favor of such a union. Moreover, closer cooperation will undoubtedly be favorable, bringing about increased productivity and prosperity.

The various measures being taken to create a united Europe will surely have wide-reaching effects, but it is difficult to predict how they will affect the sovereignty of individual countries. Any powers granted to a European government will surely have to be offset by a loss to national governments.

The European Monetary System, for example, provides a more rigid structure for Europe than individual governments have been used to. To a certain extent, this system takes the instruments of monetary policy out of the hands of national governments. It cannot for instance devalue its currency beyond a certain narrow band, as it may have done before when attempting to improve domestic industries' competitiveness, faced with international competition.

The loss of customs barriers within Europe in 1992 will, in the eyes of many people, threaten Britain's sovereignty. Internal barriers will be removed in favor of a common barrier to protect Europe as a whole. Doubts have already been cast on some countries' ability to prevent, for example, illegal immigration and drug trafficking. This form of unification will affect Britain especially, since Britain's position in Europe has always been made slightly different by the fact that it is an island. Steps towards unification (following closely the building of the Channel Tunnel) will be seen in many quarters as encroachments on this "special" situation.

The measure that will probably cause the most consternation amongst the general public of Britain will be the European Currency Unit, if it is ever widely implemented. This would affect everyone in Britain, so it would probably be the most widely opposed move. People may not notice more important edicts from Brussels wearing away their government's power, but they will certainly notice what's in their pockets.

A single Europe will surely mean a loss of sovereignty for Britain, assuming we take sovereignty to mean simply freedom for a country's national government to act in all three of its branches—executive, legislative, and judiciary—without outside interference (in this case, from the European parliament and other bodies).

However, this is not to say that we shouldn't strive to achieve it. A united Europe could be advantageous for everybody. This is not only an economic argument; all European countries can benefit from a reduction in protection of domestic industries by their government. Cohesive common markets and free trade areas help promote competitiveness and efficiency.

With 1992 now only a year away, the question of what a Single Europe will mean for Britain becomes increasingly relevant.

I firmly believe that the advent of 1992 will result in a loss of sovereignty for Britain. This loss need not, however, be negative. In fact, in political, economic, and defense terms, I feel this realignment of resources can and will be very positive. While I may be guilty of having an island mentality, I wouldn't go as far as to say Britain is in danger of handing all control over to faceless bureaucrats in Brussels or Strasbourg.

By relinquishing and thus centralizing certain powers, the aim is not to diminish the strength of individual nations but to increase the overall impact of Europe on the world stage.

After the devastations of the second World War, closer cooperation has existed among European states on all levels. First and foremost, trade treaties were established between various countries, leading to the signing of the EEC treaty in Rome, which has attracted an increasing number of members over the years. Currently, there are 12 members, and the number may expand in the future due to Eastern Europe's shift toward a market economy.

Negotiations have been intensive over the years among the various members, particularly concerning the basis of the union and the distribution of power among the European Communities' institutions. These institutions include the Council of Ministers, comprised of various ministers from member states, the Commission, and the European Parliament, which is made up of MEPs democratically elected from member states and the European Court of Justice.

The completion of the internal market, set for the year 1992, will mark a significant milestone. This will involve lifting trade barriers and establishing common policies, particularly on the social level. However, this closer union has also led to concerns about potential losses of sovereignty for member states.

Sovereignty means that a state has territorial integrity, people, and a government recognized by other countries in the world. This government makes and exercises policies without interference from other countries across economic, domestic, and foreign policy areas. It is clear that the sovereignty of European Community member states remains intact, as countries continue to make independent decisions.

However, European law, decided by the Council and the European Parliament, sometimes takes precedence over national law and is applied throughout Europe, especially concerning social matters. This is necessary for the effective functioning of the internal market in 1992. Legislation in the European institutions, involving ministers and MEPs from various countries, means that some sovereignty must be ceded.

Concerns are understandable given these circumstances. Nevertheless, crucial issues such as defense, the economy, and the actual running of the country remain in the hands of national governments. Balancing the benefits of closer cooperation with the preservation of national sovereignty continues to be a sensitive and important consideration for member states.
