It is crucial for children to understand that while there is a core of behavior that defines them as boys or girls, there are other types of behavior that are open to change. The message children receive now often perpetuates stereotypes, which can lead to many problems they encounter later in life. Men and women today need to understand and respect that they are different, as they communicate in different styles. This difference is what makes life exciting. Gender roles, like relationships, must remain dynamic, and people must know and be comfortable with who they are before they can pursue a meaningful career, relationship, or anything else that matters.

To achieve a well-adjusted, gender-relaxed adulthood society, we must amend the method and message we are giving our children. Katha Pollit does an excellent job of illustrating how television, one of the most influential sources for children, is giving kids a skewed start in shaping their ideas of what is important in being a boy or a girl. In her essay "The Smurfette Principle," she cites many painful examples of how little ones receive a terribly distorted picture of gender roles. Pollit points out that even more enlightened public broadcasting stations engage in male gender bias.

Starting girls into life's roller coaster ride with the idea that boys' lives are more important than their own is a tremendous disadvantage. It's a bad message delivered at a bad time through a bad medium. Even the best parents allow their children to watch Saturday morning cartoons, where, as Pollit cites, the most egregious errors occur. Parents allow their kids to watch these cartoons for two reasons: first, because they watched them when they were kids, and second, because parents often prioritize their own convenience over justice, seeking quiet over content.

It is important to note that these bad signals have an adverse effect on boys as well as girls. Pollit contends that the message is more straightforward for boys, perpetuating harmful stereotypes that can harm both genders in the long run.

I would like to express my opinion on the justness of the sentence handed down to Susan Smith.

Sometimes when people suffer from extreme illnesses they look for other options as an easy way out. When the pain becomes unbearable and the medication stops working some people would rather die than to continue to live in pain. Those patient's who desire to end their lives do not wish to do so on their own. They prefer to have an easy and painless death, and so they choose a form of suicide which is referred to as euthanasia. Euthanasia is a "mercy killing" for the purpose of putting an end to extreme suffering. Many of the cases concerning euthanasia in the past few years have been performed or assisted by a doctor known as Dr. Kevorkian. There has been much controversy over assisted suicides, especially those performed with the assistance of a doctor. Should it be legalized to allow doctors to assist in suicides of terminally ill patients, or should they be bound by their Hippocratic Oath?
There are several different forms of euthanasia. One form of euthanasia is when a person's life is in a permanently unconscious state, sometimes referred to as a "vegetable." When a person is in this state, if they do not have a living will stating their wishes, the family has the right to make the decision concerning whether the patient should remain on life support or not after they have consulted with the physician concerning the matter. There are very few legal objections to this form of euthanasia. It is widely practiced in hospitals all over America. Many people leave in their will expressed wishes to not be kept alive on life support systems. When the physician determines that there is no chance of a patient's
recovery, it is their duty to carry out the patient's wishes and disconnect life support. Another type of euthanasia is when a patient requests that the doctor provide no more treatment. If medical conduct to end the patient's life is prohibited, the patient is allowed maximum opportunity to change his mind and demand treatment. The patient declining treatment normally remains alive for a period and thereby receives some opportunity to change one's mind or to eliminate any mistake on the physicians part in comprehending the patient's wishes. A third type of euthanasia is self-inflicted by one's ending of one's life by means of suicide.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Sometimes when people suffer from extreme illnesses, they look for other options as an easy way out. When the pain becomes unbearable and the medication stops working, some people would rather die than continue to live in pain. Those patients who desire to end their lives do not wish to do so on their own; instead, they prefer to have an easy and painless death, thus choosing a form of suicide known as euthanasia. Euthanasia is referred to as a "mercy killing" for the purpose of putting an end to extreme suffering. Many of the cases concerning euthanasia in the past few years have involved Dr. Kevorkian, who assisted in the suicides. This has led to much controversy, particularly regarding whether it should be legalized for doctors to assist terminally ill patients or if they should be bound by their Hippocratic Oath.

There are several different forms of euthanasia. One form is when a person's life is in a permanently unconscious state, sometimes referred to as a "vegetable." In such cases, if the person does not have a living will stating their wishes, the family has the right to make the decision concerning whether the patient should remain on life support or not after consulting with the physician. This form of euthanasia is widely practiced in hospitals across America, as many people leave in their wills expressed wishes not to be kept alive on life support systems. When the physician determines that there is no chance of a patient's recovery, it is their duty to carry out the patient's wishes and disconnect life support.

Another type of euthanasia involves a patient requesting that the doctor provide no more treatment. If medical conduct to end the patient's life is prohibited, the patient is allowed maximum opportunity to change his mind and demand treatment. The patient declining treatment usually remains alive for a period, thereby receiving some opportunity to change his mind or eliminate any mistakes made by the physician in understanding the patient's wishes.

A third type of euthanasia is self-inflicted, where the patient ends his or her own life by means of suicide. This is a direct and personal choice for those facing unbearable suffering.

Lowering the drinking age would gradually change society and encourage a more mature management of alcohol.

Allowing youths to buy alcohol legally at age eighteen would prevent them from breaking the law. On most college campuses, alcohol is often involved in violent behavior or crimes, leading to major problems with underage drinking (Rick Finley@rfinleygmail.vt.edu). Lowering the drinking age would allow colleges to focus more on education rather than drinking policies. Currently, many colleges struggle with enforcing these policies (WWW.mis.duke.edu/Task-forces/Alcohol/Alcohol-chart.html).

Lowering the drinking age would also allow colleges to spend more time reforming education programs and aiding students. Allowing alcohol consumption at age eighteen would cut back on the need for reform programs since fewer people would require these services. It is the middle of July, and the temperature outside is a scorching 98 degrees. If you are like many people, the thought of going down to your local swimming pool floods your head. The only problem now is that you do not know how to swim. This is not uncommon; most of your friends do not know how to swim either. Then you realize something: you are touching the bottom of the pool, but your head is still underwater. You stand on your tip-toes, trying to get just a little bit of air into your lungs. It does not work, and now you are panicking. There is nothing you can do, and you are hoping, even praying that one of your friends will save you. ... everything goes black.

This is a common story in the summertime. You get home from work, turn on the news, and you hear of another drowning at a local pool. These are senseless deaths and could easily be avoided through education.

Drinking has been a custom in the U.S. for many decades, ever since the Wild West, the Civil War, and the drafting of the Declaration of Independence. Every since then, the legal drinking age has remained at twenty-one. However, many argue that eighteen should be the legal age for consuming alcohol in the United States. At eighteen, individuals are considered men and thus capable of making their own decisions. It seems illogical that those who are old enough to be drafted into the military can be denied the right to drink, yet are still forbidden from doing so.

Kids are dying in wars in the United States at the age of eighteen, while they are prohibited from consuming alcohol like other adults over twenty-one. This is perplexing: if one can hold a gun and fight for their country, should they not also be allowed to experience the effects of drinking? 

Many kids aged eighteen to twenty struggle to hide their drinking from their parents. Most of these teenagers are out of high school and their parents are less concerned about their actions. A high school diploma often signifies that a student is mature enough to make responsible decisions. One could argue that if a student does not have a diploma, they should not be allowed to drink. This might encourage more teenagers to pursue their education, believing that obtaining a diploma could grant them adult privileges.

Moreover, legalizing the drinking age at eighteen could potentially reduce crime among teenagers. Much of the teenage crime related to alcohol is driven by the desire to hide it from their parents. If they are not allowed to drink at home, teenagers often turn to more secretive and dangerous activities. Allowing them to drink legally could provide a safer and more socially acceptable outlet.

In conclusion, while the current drinking age of twenty-one has its reasons, many believe that lowering the legal drinking age to eighteen could lead to a decrease in teenage crime and promote a healthier, more responsible approach to alcohol consumption. Considering the maturity required to serve in the military, it seems reasonable to extend this privilege to the legal drinking age.

In an age when government funding cuts loom on the horizon like an ominous storm cloud, it leaves many to think which area of government spending will be cut next. Obviously, some areas, such as defense cuts, seem appropriate since the United States no longer is faced with the imminent threat of attack from another super-power. Yet, there are some areas, such as government support for the arts, which should keep, if not receive more, support from government agencies.
Why should the arts, both the visual and performing arts, be supported by the government? Perhaps the most general reason rests in the views of anthropology: since the beginning of human civilization, man has seen a need for interpreting and depicting his world. In this depiction, he chose to communicate in a way that would last through the ages. Thanks to the ingenuity and interpretation of primitive cultures, we still have today cave and wall drawings that communicate to us the very essence of early human thought. This is a classic model of how we of today can leave an impression for future generations. These generations will be able to look in retrospect and see what we thought was important.

Other types of contraceptives include foams, female condoms, a five-year injected tube placed in a woman's arm which releases hormones to prevent pregnancies, and a shot that acts like birth control pills but only needs to be taken every three months. All of these methods are highly effective in preventing pregnancy.

With all these protective devices available, a person has no excuse for wanting an abortion after consensual sex. Personally, I do not believe that one person has the right to take away another person's life, even if that person is not fully developed into their future self. Sure, it is supposed to be a woman's choice to say no to having a child, but this is not fair to the child. Why can't these women just carry out the pregnancy and put the child up for adoption? Additionally, some people use financial constraints as their excuse, claiming they cannot afford to have a child. The government provides aid to those in need, so financial hardship should not be a reason for abortion.

In conclusion, while I understand the perspectives of those who support women’s right to make their own decisions, I believe that strict rules regarding abortions are necessary. Encouraging the use of effective contraceptives and abstinence can help prevent unwanted pregnancies and reduce the need for abortions, ensuring that the rights and responsibilities of all parties involved are respected.

Ounce society is enlightened of these statistics, they will see that capital punishment has no place in the justice of
this country.
The first claim of supporters is that they are under the opinion that it is much more expensive to keep a convicted criminal in prison for life than to simply pull their plug.  At first glance this statement seems to be more than rational.  The problem here is that people don't realize the big picture of the situation at hand.  Instead of capital punishment saving tax payers money, it actually does the complete opposite.  Let me throw a couple of statistics at you that I gathered doing a paper last year.  Currently to administer capital punishment upon a single individ ual it costs five times the amount than it would to inprison somebody from the age of eighteen to eighty years old. Instead they are placed on death row, which on the average lasts a little over eighteen years.  During these eighteen years the convicted criminal goes up for continuous appeals. Capital punishment has been in debate since early hangings, and it will continue to be a subject of controversy until our society identifies the irrationality of its existence in our judicial system. Currently, capital punishment is being left up to the individual states as to whether or not they decide to implement it as a form of punishment. Advocates of this obscene form of punishment offer a handful of reasons justifying its use. At first glance, these reasons seem to hold up, but one by one, I will show you that these reasons are as ridiculous as the source they are trying to endorse. When society is enlightened of these statistics, they will see that capital punishment has no place in the justice of this country.

The first claim of supporters is that they believe it is much more expensive to keep a convicted criminal in prison for life than to simply execute them. At first glance, this statement seems to be more than rational. However, people don't realize the big picture of the situation at hand. Instead of capital punishment saving taxpayer money, it actually does the complete opposite. Let me throw a couple of statistics at you that I gathered while doing a paper last year: currently, to administer capital punishment upon a single individual, it costs five times the amount it would to imprison someone from the age of eighteen to eighty years old. How this statement can be valid is due to the reasons that when someone receives the death penalty, they are not executed the next day. Instead, they are placed on death row, which on average lasts a little over eighteen years. During these eighteen years, the convicted criminal goes up for continuous appeals, which are extremely expensive due to excessive court costs. When offered these facts, some try to suggest that we eliminate the appeal system. This approach is impractical because the appeal system is a major part of the backbone of our judicial system. So if the cost of punishment is at all a concern, then it is obvious that capital punishment is the wrong direction to go.

Over the past few years, a question has frequently appeared in courts: should women be allowed to attend the Citadel? Many people have voiced objections to this statement, while others stand firmly in support of it.

When questioned about why women shouldn't be admitted, the two most common responses are often the same: it has traditionally been an all-male institution, and women might not be able to handle it. Yes, the Citadel has a history of enrolling only males, but as the saying goes, traditions are meant to be broken. Traditions could never have persisted if they weren't eventually revised or discarded, such as the abolition of slavery or the end of the tradition of women being confined to household duties. As society evolves, certain practices fall by the wayside, making room for new, more equitable ones.

Despite the progress made, it's clear that society has not achieved complete equality. Men and women, though sharing many similarities, also differ significantly. Some women, like some men, may be strong and intelligent, while others might not. It's not fair to assume that women, as a whole, cannot handle the challenges of attending the Citadel. While some might argue that women lack the physical strength required, there are certainly women who could meet these demands. The key is that everyone deserves the opportunity to try.

In our country, if a school is publicly funded, it cannot discriminate against race, religion, gender, or people with disabilities. The Citadel, as a publicly funded institution, should not be any different. If public schools started to implement discriminatory practices, such as restricting admission based on ethnicity or nationality, it would create great chaos in our education system. This would necessitate additional resources, such as more teachers, bus drivers, janitors, and cooks, to accommodate the increased student population.

In conclusion, the Citadel, like all public schools, should follow the same principles of equality and non-discrimination. By allowing women to attend, we can move closer to a more equitable society where people are judged on their abilities and character, rather than their gender.

The debate over whether Marijuana should be legalized has been ongoing since the 1960s, and it remains a significant issue today. In 1980, the FDA began prescribing THC pills, the active ingredient in Marijuana, to control nausea in cancer patients, and more recently, Marijuana cigarettes to patients suffering from glaucoma to increase appetite. Despite this, over 400,000 people in the U.S. are arrested each year on marijuana charges.

Who is responsible for prohibiting the reading and studying of certain texts? This authority typically rests with school boards of education, parents within various school districts, or censorship groups such as the Citizens for Excellence in Education (CEE). But who endowed these individuals or groups with the power to ban books? The Constitution of the United States, as I last recall, provided all people with the freedom of speech. However, since Johannes Gutenberg's printing press in 1455 and Pope Leo X's condemnation of Martin Luther's Ninety-Five Theses, materials have been censored viewed as dangerous or threatening to society.

In more recent times, censorship has taken more extreme forms, with some groups even resorting to burning books they deem inappropriate. Did you know that in the 1991-92 academic year, the People of the American Way (PAW) reported in their journal, Attacks on the Freedom of Speech, that 376 attacks were made on the freedom to learn? Additionally, 348 demands were made for the removal of certain texts from school curricula and public libraries, involving 44 out of the 50 states.

Nashua Board of Education, the board failed to provide a legitimate reason for banning the magazine, resulting in its return to the school library.

Board of Education, where it was established that the teachers' First Amendment rights were violated. Despite the First Amendment granting teachers the right to choose their textbooks, their rights were waived under a previous agreement with the school district.

As if the limitations on the teaching curriculum and student education due to constant attempts by groups such as CEE, the Blackstone Society, and the Rutherford Institute were not enough, many public libraries are also feeling the strain.

In Ralph Ellison's *The Invisible Man*, he urges African Americans to strive for recognition and equality in a society that often overlooks them. Phillis Wheatley also exhorts African Americans to embrace the metaphorical "angelic train," which symbolizes their journey to a brighter future. Ethnic American writers like Ellison and Wheatley are encouraging their communities to join and accept the white-dominated America. However, this acceptance is often unreciprocated; white society tolerates other ethnicities but rarely fully embraces them. Maxine Hong Kingston highlights this in "Reparation Candy," where a drug store clerk hands out candy under the mistaken belief that the customers are beggars, instead of recognizing the candy's purpose of warding off a curse. This act demonstrates a superficial form of tolerance. Barbara Rice Cleary offers deeper insights into cultural acceptance, emphasizing the necessity for genuine understanding and integration among all Americans. Barbara Rice also points out that true acceptance involves acknowledging and valuing the rich diversity each culture brings to the American tapestry.

Reading ethnic American literature illuminates the harm caused by nonacceptance. The spirituals sung by African Americans vividly express their longing for a more welcoming world. One spiritual says, "Free at last, Free at last, Thank God Almighty, We are Free at Last." These songs articulate the African American desire to leave a place that rejects them and seek a home where they are accepted. Martin Luther King Jr. echoed this sentiment, calling for a change in non-accepting attitudes and advocating for all Americans to see each other as brothers and sisters. Ozzie, in Roth's *The Conversion of the Jews*, pleads for acceptance when he cries, "Mother, let us not count the names of only the Jews who died." He wants all the deaths mourned, not just those of his own people. Similarly, in Amy Tan's *The Joy Luck Club*, June cries out for acceptance, weary of her mother's relentless efforts to turn her into a "prodigy." She yearns to be accepted as she is, and in her struggle, she even attempts to suppress her Chinese heritage. But ultimately, she recognizes that her identity is inseparable from her blood and cannot be denied.

Nonacceptance is harmful, perpetuating division and preventing the true richness of America from flourishing.

The American Heritage dictionary defines culture as the "...set of human achievements, including intellectual and artistic expressions, beliefs, and social habits, which distinguish a society or group." The transmission of culture is a very important aspect of ethnic American literature. Many ethnic American writers demonstrate the significance of passing down culture or tradition from one generation to the next, possibly to preserve the customs and traditions of their native country.

Many of the novels we have read this semester illustrate this aspect of transmitting culture. For example, Amy Tan's "The Joy Luck Club" prominently features the desire of the mothers to hold on to the old ways of China and raise their daughters "the Chinese way." The mothers share stories of China with their daughters, aiming to convey information about their heritage—where they came from, who they are, and why they act in certain ways regarding specific issues. The daughters, however, find it challenging to understand because they have been Americanized. By the end of the novel, all the daughters come to understand their foreign mothers and learn to accept their traditions, thus opening the doors for the transmission of culture. Amy Tan's novel concludes with this significant aspect of ethnic literature.

Another novel that illustrates the transmission of culture is Alice Walker's "The Color Purple." Celie's sister Nettie travels to Africa as a missionary and attempts to transmit African-American culture to the natives. Additionally, in Laura Esquivel's "Like Water for Chocolate," Mama Elena tries to transmit culture to Tita and her other daughters. Although Mama Elena fails miserably with Tita and Gertrudes, she manages to influence Rosaura with the old ways. These examples from various novels highlight the diverse methods and challenges involved in the transmission of culture within ethnic American literature.

When Voltaire wrote Candide, a literary style known as Neoclassicism was at its peak. There was a group of scholars in France, l'Academie Français, that set guidelines for French literature. According to l'Academie Français, all literature of the Neoclassic period must follow the rules of propriety which regulated the author should avoid certain topics, including sex, violence, church, and state issues. Another standard upheld by the Academie is the idea of verisimilitude, making literature as realistic as possible by keeping the time, setting and plot true to life. Voltaire, as a Neoclassicist, knew all these regulations and followed them in his literature.  However, when writing Candide, Voltaire defied the Academie's rules. Candide is a parody on the guidelines of Neoclassicism.  
Neoclassicists liked for literature to have good manners: they did not want to step on anyone's toes by mentioning sex, violence, church, or state issues. When Voltaire wrote Candide, a literary style known as Neoclassicism was at its peak. There was a group of scholars in France, l'Academie Française, that set guidelines for French literature. Another standard upheld by the Academie is the idea of verisimilitude, making literature as realistic as possible by keeping the time, setting, and plot true to life. Traffic jams are becoming larger and more frequent. Trains are never on time. Everybody always has a complaint about some part of the transport system in the United Kingdom. What is wrong, and what can we do about it?

The amount of criticism aimed at the British rail network increases daily, and not without reason. Much of the rolling stock is old, slow, noisy, and uncomfortable. Passengers who seem to revolve around annoying others—listening to not-quite-personal stereos, smoking in non-smoking sections, putting bags on seats—are a common sight on trains. All this makes the train less appealing to the general public, and, in particular, the commuter.

Another problem is understaffing, both on trains and at stations. This leads to an increase in fare dodging, which is now quite possible unintentionally—especially with ticket offices closed at both ends of the journey and no guards to give receipts to. All this results in trains being unprofitable, except on a few major commuter routes. Many things have been tried to reverse this, but to no avail. Closing small lines that regularly lose money may seem sensible, but it leads to fewer people using trains in general. After all, if you have to drive twenty miles to the nearest station, you might as well just drive to wherever you are going. Increasing or decreasing prices could also be tried, but since trains are already more expensive than cars for most journeys, this would have little effect.

The only way to make profits is to get more people on trains, which requires an improvement in services. This would initially cost a lot, and unfortunately, sufficient funding is never available. As more and more people use cars, traffic in city centers during rush hours comes to a near standstill. More cars arrive, get stuck in jams, and spread the congestion further and further out of the city until even motorways and bypasses become blocked.

The problem is obvious: there are too many cars on Britain's roads. There are two ways around the problem: reduce the number of cars or build more roads. In cities, where all traffic jams start, there is no room for more roads—every square yard is already in use. The only place more roads can be built is outside cities, where more and wider motorways could be constructed.

It cannot help but be noticed that Britain's roads are becoming increasingly unsavoury places. Congestion is a severe problem, particularly in urban areas, where it is very difficult - almost impossible in fact -to create new road systems to cope with the taffic. The emissions from diesel vehicles - cars, buses and lorries - are particularly harmful (just watch a bus start its engine, and observe the huge black cloud that belches forth from its exhaust pipe), and yet there is no control on these vehicles' exhaust.
Hundreds of people are killed on the roads every year, and as cars become faster and taffic denser, the number of accidents will surely increase. Cars are also an extremely inefficient way of transporting people - large amounts of energy are used, and very often the car is only carrying one person. The number of lorries around is increasing, as more and more freight is carried by road (as opposed to sea or rail), due to the influence exerted by the road-haulage lobby on the government. Lorries create more noise and pollution than cars, and are much more damaging to the roads they travel on.
Now that rail privatisation has gone ahead, many people are likely to lose faith in trains, due to the percieved inefficiency of the operators (for example the time-table book full of errors or the recent survey in Which? magazine about overcharging). Fares are likely to increase, and many rural lines that used to be subsidised by the government face closure. Very little freight is transposed by rail these days, so the railways have lost income due to this.<|end|><|assistant|>

Britain's roads are becoming increasingly unsavoury places, marked by severe congestion, especially in urban areas. Creating new road systems to cope with the traffic is almost impossible. For instance, a journey into Lancaster may only take ten minutes when the roads are quiet, but can take three-quarters of an hour during the 'rush-hour.' Congestion is certainly not a problem that will go away; the number of cars on Britain's roads is increasing constantly. The M25 has already been dubbed 'the biggest car-park in Europe,' and if current trends continue, the number of cars using it will double by 2030.

A huge amount of pollution is chewed out by all those cars, contributing to global warming, acid rain, and smog in cities. Although catalytic converters are now compulsory on new cars, the fumes in cities have become so bad that scientists have linked them to a marked increase in the number of asthma sufferers. The emissions from diesel vehicles—cars, buses, and lorries—are particularly harmful. For example, just watch a bus start its engine, and observe the huge black cloud that belches forth from its exhaust pipe, and you'll see the extent of the pollution. Yet, there is no control on these vehicles' exhaust.

Hundreds of people are killed on the roads every year, and as cars become faster and traffic denser, the number of accidents will surely increase. Cars are also an extremely inefficient way of transporting people: large amounts of energy are used, and very often the car is only carrying one person. The number of lorries around is increasing, as more and more freight is carried by road, due to the influence exerted by the road-haulage lobby on the government. Lorries create more noise and pollution than cars and are much more damaging to the roads they travel on.

Now that rail privatisation has gone ahead, many people are likely to lose faith in trains due to perceived inefficiency. For example, the time-table book is often full of errors, and a recent survey in Which? magazine revealed issues with overcharging. Fares are likely to increase, and many rural lines that used to be subsidised by the government face closure. Very little freight is transposed by rail these days, so the railways have lost income due to this.

The United Kingdom, a small island with a population of around 55 million, is experiencing significant overpopulation. This has led to an inadequate and expensive public transport system, forcing more and more cars onto the road. As a result, Britain now has the most cars per mile of road anywhere in the world, and current modern traffic policies are insufficient to address this problem. In short, a somewhat more radical and unpopular policy is required.

British rail is notoriously slow, late, and expensive. The excitement of rail travel and steam trains has long since faded, with many old tracks being dismantled. To alleviate the congestion on Britain's roads, it is essential to encourage more rail travel. Opening new lines rather than closing old ones could help. Simply widening and building new roads will not solve the problem, as the number of cars will continue to rise to fill the gaps. The recent halt of work on the Newbury bypass for three days highlights the growing frustration with road congestion. We are running out of room to build new roads.

One of the main consequences of road travel is pollution. Issues such as acid rain and asthma are now common, and soon we may run out of resources to fuel these cars. While gas buses and gas stations are only a short-term solution, a renewable source must be found. However, petrol companies' reluctance to invest in alternative fuels like water and alcohol, fearing loss of petrol sales, makes these options seem distant as our primary form of transport.

In conclusion, the solutions for these problems in Britain have been unimaginative and largely unsuccessful. A more radical approach to improving public transportation and addressing road congestion is necessary to create a sustainable and efficient future for the country's transportation system.

There are many problems facing both road and rail transport in the UK. Among the most discussed issues concerning road transport are congestion and safety. Congestion is particularly evident around major conurbations such as London, Greater Manchester, and Birmingham. One simple solution to this problem would be to build more roads or make the existing ones larger. However, as seen in recent events like the Newbury incident, this approach has faced strong opposition from environmental groups and local residents. An alternative way to reduce congestion, especially in large cities, is to persuade people to refrain from using their vehicles at all. On Britain's roads, there is an ever-increasing volume of traffic, and the road network is no longer able to manage this traffic without hold-ups and traffic jams. To address this issue, the government has begun adding a fourth lane to some stretches of our motorways and constructing ring roads and bypasses, although these improvements have received mixed reception. As the road system is being improved, there seems to be an endless series of roadworks that further restrict highways and cause additional delays while the roadworks are in place. The main disadvantage with the railways is that, since the rail service and the bus service are normally owned by different companies, it is unlikely that one could simply walk onto a bus from a train. This would make it more convenient for people to catch the train, eliminating the need to wait around for a bus or an expensive taxi ride.

Travelling by motorway today is not as easy as it was intended to be by any standards. Every morning and evening, motorways across the United Kingdom are blocked solid with traffic, both to and from work. Not only is this situation 'ecologically' unsound due to the harmful byproducts of the combustion engine, which has been stressed in the press recently, but it is also stressful, time-wasting, and expensive. Earth has a finite supply of fossil fuels, from which petroleum and diesel fuel our cars and trains. We still have a need to get to work, which could be anything up to 200 miles away.

Not only are there problems traveling from point A to point B, but if B is any major city, you might also waste more time looking for a place to park. During pre-war Britain, rail was the only means of long-distance travel within the UK, making the rail system more efficient with more frequent trains and many more stations. However, as the motor car became more popular, fewer people used the rail system, leading to its decline. The smaller demand resulted in less frequent services and increased prices.

In my opinion, the only way forward is to increase the use of public transport systems due to the sheer waste caused by the average two-car family. The majority of the cars you will see traveling at a snail's pace along the M6 outside Birmingham will be driven by one person with no passengers. If these drivers had offered a colleague from work a lift home, the number of cars on the road would effectively be halved.

Cities such as Manchester have tried to control the increasing number of cars by introducing bypasses and providing multi-storey car parking. Some cities have even banned cars from entering during work hours to make pedestrian life more enjoyable. Trams have been re-established in some cities, allowing people to leave their cars for shopping. This attitude should be adopted not only by town and city councils but also by the government to reduce the number of cars on the road.

Although Britain is said to have the oldest democracy in the world, however, this democracy can often appear antiquated, old-fashioned, and unfair. There has not been a wholesale reform of the electoral system in Britain since women were granted the vote in the 1920s. This only allowed a growth in the electorate, but the system of voting has not changed since the last century, making Britain an undemocratic country.

The system used within Britain is known as the "First past the post" system. This system of direct constituencies elects the candidate with the largest number of votes. This means that in many areas, candidates are elected with under 50% of the total vote within that constituency. These successful candidates move on to the House of Commons to become MPs. This creates a House of Representatives voted in by a minority vote in many cases, with the only exceptions being very safe seats like Huntington and Islington. This has led to instances such as the 1970 general election when the Conservative victory under Edward Heath was achieved with fewer votes than the main opposition party. Many would argue that the weaknesses and unfairness of this system are apparent and should be changed.

However, there are strengths to this system. The First past the post system always leads to strong governments, usually leaving the governing party with a workable majority. Much of the work, bringing Britain into the modern economic world, done by the Conservatives in the early 1960s, was achieved through the First past the post system. The other option, proportional representation, is seen to give more say to the electorate on who gets elected, but unfortunatly, this system can lead to weak governments, allowing the growth of political extremist parties and even Members of Parliament who may not have the overall vote. This can result in weak governments, especially within Britain's three-party system, where the balance of power is always held by the Liberal Democrats and the National Parties.

The British parliamentary electoral system is often criticized as unfair and undemocratic, though I believe it remains the best foundation for government. Consider a general election in which three parties, X, Y, and Z, compete in a country of 5000 voters. Suppose 2000 people vote for party X, while 1500 vote for parties Y and Z combined. Party X would come into power due to having the most votes. However, there are 3000 people who do not want them in power, which is not the majority of the country. This raises concerns about the true representation of the electorate.

Furthermore, the idea of each constituency having an MP who fights for its beliefs in parliament has significant flaws. For instance, consider the situation when an MP decides to switch parties. Voters typically vote on how the party, which the MP represents, is performing at that moment. Once a party is in government, it is free to change its policies until the next general election, during which it may make hollow promises to gain votes.

Indeed, while this system has its shortcomings, it is worth noting that other forms of government, such as dictatorships, also face severe challenges. Dictatorships can lead to economic disasters not only within the country itself but also in related nations.

In my view, the British system, despite its flaws, is the best we have. There is no perfect way to run a country. Every system will inevitably please some people at some times, but not all people all of the time. The only possible fair system of government is likely to involve a small group of about ten people, but even then, people are bound to be discontent.

An issue that is becoming increasingly debated is whether or not fox hunting should be banned. In today's society, it is seen as an outdated and barbaric "sport" which, in my opinion, should be banned. Animal rights have been a topic of discussion in Parliament, and many measures have been implemented to safeguard animal welfare. Recently, the British government has introduced legislation concerning the transportation of animals destined for slaughter, including regulations on the time spent on the road and the amount of space provided. However, it remains perfectly legal for a group of people to chase a fox with a pack of dogs and then watch the exhausted fox be torn apart by the dogs.

This appears to be unfair and hypocritical, as it is also illegal for two dogs to attack each other for the enjoyment of spectators. At least in the case of fighting one dog against another, there is some semblance of fairness. However, it remains perfectly legal for an infinite number of dogs to attack a single fox for the enjoyment of others. The fox stands no chance; why is fox hunting legal when all other blood sports are banned?

Fox hunting is predominantly enjoyed by the upper class, as it requires a horse, dogs, and riding equipment (such as helmets and boots). It also necessitates land to carry out the hunt. Since the beginning of mankind, we have always detected, stalked, captured, and killed prey, which was essential for our survival. In the modern world, there is no need to hunt for food. This raises the moral issue: is it right and just to kill animals if we aren't going to eat them? Are blood sports acceptable in today's society?

Two men, one ring, only one can leave. This dramatic premise is at the core of boxing, although rules have been introduced over the years to mitigate its more brutal aspects. The question remains: Should boxing be banned?

This can lead to the loss of numerous brain cells per fight, and if this occurs frequently, it can result in brain damage, effectively ending a boxer's career. Despite its violent nature, some argue that boxing is more than a blood sport. Chris Eubank, for instance, views himself as a sportsman and believes that boxing is an art form. However, one tragic incident stands out: Michael Watson, who was put into a coma by Chris Eubank, the very man who argues that boxing is an art, not a fight to the finish. This example starkly highlights the inherent dangers of boxing.

The boxing federation has made efforts to make the sport safer, such as having ring-side doctors and banning bare-knuckle fights. However, the primary issue remains that any blow to the head can cause significant damage, regardless of these measures. Therefore, the debate over whether boxing should remain legal or be banned continues, largely due to its dangerous consequences.

The National Lottery was introduced to Britain in November 1994 and has since become increasingly popular, involving millions of people across the country each week. However, the proposal of a lottery brought about many objections and complaints, particularly from the Anti-National Lottery Campaigners. These campaigners have two primary concerns. First, for people living in high society, a 'flutter' on the National Lottery each week has no effect on their financial position, as they can afford to spend £10-20 a week. The concern lies for working-class citizens, who work hard throughout the year and cannot afford to spend copious amounts of money on the lottery. These working men and women, as well as unemployed men and women, do spend money they can't afford.

The second of these problems is the encouragement of gambling. The National Lottery is essentially another gambling game, with the probability of winning the jackpot being approximately 1 in 14 million and the probability of winning ten pounds being 1 in 58. It is gambling, and more importantly, it is gambling made available to 16-year-olds. A lot of gambling problems tend to lie with the scratch cards associated with the lottery, which are easily purchased and offer the immediate gratification of winning. This instant appeal to being rich encourages both young and old to purchase tickets.

Despite these concerns, the National Lottery also has its good points. One main advantage is that it has helped charities and societies around the country achieve things that would otherwise have been impossible. For example, it has facilitated the purchase of expensive stimulative equipment for a young child with brain problems and the construction of a new village hall for a small community in the Shetland Islands. The lottery has helped both young and old, far and wide.

Additionally, the National Lottery has created jobs, encouraged spending, and has made many people have happy dreams about what it would be like to be rich. In conclusion, the National Lottery has its good points and its bad points. Deciding whether it should have been introduced is a personal decision that depends on how much importance you place on the points I have emphasized in this essay. I believe it is a benefit to the country.

By the laws of averages, the population stands to lose out as only fifty percent of money is allocated to the prizes, leading to more 'super-rich' people and reducing the financial capabilities of those at the lower end of the spectrum. The spread of wealth across Britain is uneven enough as it is. The lottery would create a vicious circle where the only way to pay off gambling debts would be to win, thereby increasing the problem.

There were two main objections raised against the introduction of the national lottery. The first was the objection that the lottery would essentially be another form of taxation, particularly burdening the poor. The second, and more significant, objection came from charities, who predicted a decline in charitable donations as people would be less likely to give money to charity and instead buy lottery tickets, using the justification that some of the money spent on tickets would go to charity.

Additionally, there was controversy regarding the awarding of the lottery organization franchise, which went to Camelot, not seen as the strongest contender. Since its introduction, the national lottery has faced more controversy. In 2006, it promised to give 45 pence in every pound to charitable causes, but failed to ensure that most, if not all, of this money would actually go to charity. Moreover, there has been controversy over the allocation of funds. For example, 3 million pounds were given to Eton College, one of the richest public schools in the UK, for a gymnasium, and money was also allocated to the Royal Opera House.

The lottery has also been accused of being addictive, particularly with the introduction of scratch cards. It has been claimed that people become so addicted that they spend all their available cash on lottery tickets, only to be disappointed when they don't win.

Despite promises, only a small fraction of lottery revenue actually benefits charity, and winning substantial prizes remains incredibly rare.

National Lottery draws have become a regular part of Saturday nights for many British families. Some people have achieved millionaire status overnight due to their lucky numbers being selected. However, before the first draw took place, heated debate ensued regarding the existence of the National Lottery.

During the debate, many interested parties voiced their objections. One of Britain's most famous businesses and families, particularly the 'pool' companies and Littlewoods, expressed strong concerns about the inception of the National Lottery. They feared that people would spend their money on the lottery instead of contributing to the 'pools,' which would lead to a decline in their business. They argued that this shift would result in job losses, exacerbating the existing unemployment issues in Merseyside.

Charities also expressed worries about the National Lottery's impact. They had been promised a share of the profits, amounting to approximately 40p of every pound spent. However, calculations indicated that charities would likely be disadvantaged, as the introduction of the lottery could reduce the funds collected through scratch card sales—a significant source of income for charitable organizations. Additionally, charities were concerned that their scratch cards, which could not offer large cash prizes, would be less appealing to customers, further diminishing their revenue.

The debate also centered on which organizations would benefit from the lottery's profits. Charities expected a fair share, but several other groups expressed interest in receiving funds. Applications were submitted to the National Heritage Office, with proposals to allocate money toward building monuments commemorating the millennium's start. While many people supported this idea, they opposed the construction of unnecessary 'White Elephants.'

Sports teams, clubs, social groups, and communities also applied for cash to fund new facilities. John Major announced that some lottery profits would be used for the construction of a British Academy of Sport. However, concerns arose about the equitable distribution of the funds. Many people questioned whether the lottery's profits would help bridge the North-South divide or if it would further deepen regional disparities.

When the national lottery was first introduced in November of 1994, many objections were raised about various different aspects of the lottery. Firstly, before the lottery actually started, there was conflict between two parties over who should actually run the lottery. These two parties were Michael Bronson's 'Virgin' group and another independent group, 'Camelot.' When it was decided that 'Camelot' were to run the lottery, Richard Bronson objected on the grounds that 'Camelot' intended to take a share of the profits of the National Lottery, as far as donating a percentage to good causes, such as various local support groups—hospitals, the Millennium Fund, and other more prominent charities. This concern has been seen to become a problem, as people from low socio-economic groups have spent more on the lottery than others, hoping for a quick fortune. This issue was linked to the fact that young people, particularly those under sixteen, would also become hooked on the lottery, a problem that more conservative groups felt could become as addictive as alcohol or drugs to young people.

Finally, the last major objection was the possibility of one single individual winning a sum of as much as £40 million. Groups such as church teachers felt that this was too much money for one person to have when there were so many problems such as famine and homelessness in the world. They also questioned how such an amount of money would affect an individual's personal life. These concerns highlighted the broader implications of the lottery's introduction and the potential consequences for society.

I believe that the computer has made us both use and not use our brains for various reasons. To begin with, the introduction of computers has made us think more due to the numerous programs we use on them. Learning how to use these programs can take quite some time. Furthermore, once a program or computer is introduced, it quickly becomes outdated as people are thinking about how to improve it. It is important to remember that computers cannot replace the human brain (not yet, at least).

On the other hand, using computers does not necessarily stop us from using our brains; instead, they serve as quick and efficient time savers. For instance, someone is undoubtedly relieved to use a word processing program rather than struggle with an old-fashioned typewriter. Imagine the frustration of making a mistake while writing an important letter with a typewriter—yes, you would have to start again. In contrast, with a computer, making a mistake is much easier to correct.

Some people claim that computer games do not require a brain to be played. However, certain games are so challenging that people worldwide collaborate on how to solve them. They communicate through computers, which is a quicker and more efficient method than traditional means. While some games might require only pressing a button, others demand significant brainpower and strategic thinking, thereby engaging our brains in ways that simpler games do not.

Despite the benefits of computers in saving time, they also do everything for us with just a touch of a button. They solve difficult sums, check spelling errors, and handle various other tasks. This convenience can lead to us relying less on our brains for mundane tasks.

From simple homework assignments to the complex operations of running a nuclear power station like Heysham's, computers handle much of the work. For instance, at Heysham's Nuclear Power Station, a single man operates the facility, assisted by millions of pounds' worth of computers. This situation makes it hard to see the need for much brain power.

Moreover, computers are capable of communicating with each other, flying planes, building cars, and even running a country. Thus, while they undoubtedly save time and make life easier, they also influence how we use our brains by handling tasks that would otherwise require significant mental effort.

The human brain is the most powerful computer known to man, yet it is small and light. It serves as the control center of the body, allowing it to move freely around its surroundings, interact with other humans, and objects. The brain can make decisions, communicate, and, most notably, rival computers in memory capacity. Some of the brain's functions, such as those in accountancy, have been taken over by computers, particularly with the invention of electronic calculators. These calculators have made the entire field of mathematics quicker, though they haven't changed the subject itself; rather, they have solved a few mathematical puzzles.

Computers, however, have achieved unimaginable accuracy. Most high-precision engineering projects today utilize computers and laser technology to create parts accurate to thousandths of a millimeter. Despite the widespread use of computers in the modern world, they remain primarily an aid to the brain. Humans still have to tell computers what to do, maintaining control over these machines. The human brain is in no way made redundant by the invention of the computer, and it is unlikely that technology will soon discover a way to create an electronic machine capable of competing with the brain for any of its functions, let alone all of them.

The computer has been one of the most influential inventions of all time, dominating the majority of government business, science, and communication, as well as many other areas of human life. In many ways, it has taken the place of the human brain in performing calculations and thought processes.

The most obvious example of this is the calculator, an instrument used by mathematicians and scientists for making numerical calculations. This has made it no longer necessary for the human to perform calculations and run through equations, and so needed to understand the principles behind them any longer. Although this may seem an extreme view, as there is still much in the world of mathematics and science that a computer cannot calculate, this may not be the case centuries into the future.

Computers have also been used as a means of keeping records, all but superseding handwritten text. In a few decades, people may well be faced with a computer screen and keyboard in their General Studies exam. They are used to transfer money across the globe, create artwork, and entertain. Computer-generated pictures, including fractal images drawn from equations, seem to be more popular than hand-printed images from an artist's imagination. Computer games also provide more entertainment than any game or activity that takes place in the real, physical world. Virtual reality allows people to have "3-D" entertainment created for them by a computer.

Whether or not the computer is taking over from the human brain, it has certainly made the human body all but redundant. People, businesses, or corporations can be contacted at any point around the globe by fax machines, e-mail, and the internet, and some people prefer these forms of communication to meeting face to face. Money can be transferred instantly without even needing to move the actual money—the physical coinage doesn't matter; it is the computer records that state how much each bank has ownership of.

However, the idea that the human brain is no longer useful is not entirely true. Computers cannot deal with human beings, have no capacity for coping with anything outside their expected situations, and cannot adapt to new situations using judgment.

Such developments have made the human brain more dependent on the computer due to its increased usage, which has rendered various parts of the brain lazy. Many people argue nowadays that, with the advent of computer technology, our mental arithmetic is poor and we are becoming a nation of couch potatos. It is true in a way, the development of portable calculating machines (calculators) has meant that we no longer need to be able to work out sums in our heads, but at what cost? In many shops, the cashiers appear to be dumbfounded by the simplest of sums without the aid of their tills.
		In many areas, the skill of human judgement has been replaced by faster, more accurate, computers. Many people have had their job positions taken over by computers. Filing cabinets are becoming a thing of the past with computer databases. But even such menial tasks as filing are good for us. They encourage organisational skills and tidiness.
	When people talk about artificial intelligence (AI), you hear many funny tales from people who are convinced that the computers are coming alive and will eventually rule us. These are just the rantings of people who have nothing to do with computers and who do not realise that behind every computer is a programmer. Even `artificial intelligence' needs to be programmed. Human brains still work out how to build the computers, how to program them and, more importantly, how to control them.
	As for making the human brain redundant computers can help to improve learning skills, they can teach, test and improve our linguistic skills. Reflexes are improved (and this has been scientifically proven) by playing computer games, the very same things that parents say turn their children into `zombies'. 	The computer revolution has not made our brains redundant, it has opened up areas of them we never knew existed!

result:
Many people argue nowadays that, with the advent of computer technology, our mental arithmetic is poor and we are becoming a nation of couch potatos. It is true in a way, the development of portable calculating machines (calculators) has meant that we no longer need to be able to work out sums in our heads. However, this brings us to question the cost of such convenience. In many shops, the cashiers appear to be dumbfounded by the simplest of sums without the aid of their tills, highlighting a decline in basic numerical skills.

In many areas, the skill of human judgment has been replaced by faster, more accurate computers. Many people have had their job positions taken over by computers, and even menial tasks such as filing have been outsourced to computer databases. Yet, even these tasks can encourage organizational skills and tidiness.

When people talk about artificial intelligence (AI), many funny tales emerge from those convinced that computers are coming alive and will eventually rule us. These are just the rantings of people who have nothing to do with computers and who do not realize that behind every computer is a programmer. Even "artificial intelligence" needs to be programmed, and human brains still work out how to build the computers, how to program them, and, more importantly, how to control them.

As for making the human brain redundant, computers can actually help to improve learning skills, teaching, testing, and enhancing our linguistic abilities. Reflexes are improved (and this has been scientifically proven) by playing computer games—an activity that parents often claim turns their children into "zombies." We can expand our imagination and convert our ideas into computer-simulated models, enabling us to design buildings and road networks.

In conclusion, the computer revolution has not made our brains redundant; it has opened up areas of them we never knew existed.

It is now the age of the computer. Almost everyone owns a computer or has access to one. Computers nowadays are a far cry from the ones in the past, which filled whole rooms. They can generate amazingly accurate graphical representations and perform extremely difficult mathematical equations in just seconds.

Computers have become a huge part of our lives in both the areas of work and education. But are they such a good thing? When calculators came along, a drop in the ability of students for mental arithmetic was obvious, and now they are used for the simplest calculations. The computer could do the same thing. Computers encourage laziness in the general public; why work something out yourself when the computer can do it for you? This is very time-saving and efficient, but it is causing people to forget basic ideas. For instance, spelling is no longer as important as it was—you can simply use a "spellcheck" to correct your English, which is absurd.

For the youth of today, computers offer links around the world and millions of facts and figures, which could be argued to be educational. However, this is killing the imagination of children. They spend hours sat at a keyboard, tapping away in the doom and gloom of the house. They should be out enjoying themselves and gaining experiences for themselves instead of reading about them on a flat screen.

It is said that you can meet people through computers and have "relationships." I find this preposterous, and people are losing the ability to communicate and form relationships. Computers can offer an escape from the hum-drum routine of daily life by means of games, but they are mind-numbing and un-inventive.

There is, however, a more dangerous threat from computers: they can do the work for man. This could lead to high unemployment. Those who work with computers for long periods of time every day face problems. Repetition of tapping keys all day and staring at the screen can be harmful and not only that; it is highly boring to do the same thing over and over again.

Computers may be the future, but what part will man have in this future?

In analyzing how far the invention of the computer has made the human brain redundant, we must recognize that changes in the demand for computers have not been universal. While "Western" developed countries have popularized the computer, developing countries have been left behind due to lower education levels and cultural barriers that hinder mass computer demand.

The invention of the computer has facilitated further technological advancements that benefit industry. For instance, robotic production of cars has allowed many firms to increase their efficiency and productivity. The people in the United Kingdom will cease to eat beef if they see more evidence that it is related to the human equivalent of "mad cow's disease," or BSE, as it is also known. The government claims that it will not affect humans, while tabloids argue that it will if we eat it. However, the recent experiment on mice, which allegedly proved that there is no link between BSE and the human equivalent, was not seen as convincing evidence by the government.

If the papers continue to emphasize that "beef is bad for you," the people will eventually stop eating beef and choose a suitable replacement, such as lamb. If beef is removed from public awareness, it will likewise fade from people's minds, along with concerns about Salmonella, killer bugs, and other issues the press bring to light.

Schools and some hospitals have already been promoting "beef-free" environments, and this trend is increasing, causing a decrease in the demand for beef in the U.K. This decrease in demand is leading to a significant drop in beef prices, in turn causing a decline in the income of farmers and the industry as a whole. The simple supply and demand curve illustrates how a fall in demand for beef leads to a drop in prices, as farmers are unlikely to reduce supply drastically, which would result in widespread slaughter and disposal of hundreds of beef cattle. To survive, the beef industry may need to reduce supply but altering supply in the agricultural sector is inherently challenging.

If no-one wants to eat beef then cows will only be bred for their milk, which means there will be less cows in the future possibly. If cows are no longer required by the public for food, some abbattoir workers may lose jobs, and several butchers, to whom the money from beef products is a considerable percentage of their income, may be hit hard by this.
The politicians still say it is safe, and that they will continue to eat beef.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Scientists believe that it may not be safe to eat beef products. Several years ago, the disease BSE, also known as 'Mad Cow Disease,' became quite commonplace among cattle. This disease causes severe mental deficiency, preventing the cow from thinking for itself, and ultimately leading to its death. Alarmingly, BSE has been known to cross animal barriers, as several sheep have exhibited similar symptoms after consuming feed made from the remnants of dead, meat-stripped cows. Currently, there are growing concerns that BSE may have crossed the boundary between cows and humans, as cases of Creutzfeld-Jacob Disease (CJD) have been increasingly reported. There is no known cure for CJD, and the only way humans could contract it would be through the consumption of beef products. This has understandably put many people off beef, especially considering the press's coverage of the government's inefficient quality control and the fact that this issue has been ongoing for years. The disease can take up to 15-20 years to become evident in humans, meaning that even if people stopped eating beef today, they would still face a risk of contracting CJD in the future. However, discontinuing beef consumption now would reduce the likelihood of future CJD cases.

If a significant number of people decided to give up beef products, this would have profound effects on the agricultural industry. Cattle farmers, in particular, would be severely impacted if consumers stopped purchasing their meat. The demand for meat from other animals, such as sheep and pigs, would likely increase as people sought alternatives to beef. This shift could potentially lower beef prices as the market adjusts, possibly leading consumers to take the minimal risk of purchasing beef instead of opting for more expensive alternatives. If the demand for beef dwindled, cows might primarily be bred for their milk production, potentially reducing the overall cow population. This reduction could result in job losses among dairy workers and butchers, who rely heavily on beef sales for a substantial portion of their income.

Despite these concerns, politicians continue to assure the public that beef consumption is safe and that they will continue to eat it.

The people of the U.K. appear to be shifting away from eating beef, and I believe there are two main reasons for this trend: i.) the BSE problem and ii.) the rise of vegetarianism.

i.) BSE, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy, has been a disease affecting sheep (scrapie), cattle (BSE), and humans (CJD) for some time. All three diseases progress similarly, likely due to the same infectious agents, known as prions, which are tiny non-living infectious particles. To cause harm, these prions must be actively ingested by an animal. They are incredibly resilient to heat, meaning cooking affected food does not eliminate the risk. When BSE first surfaced in the media years ago, there was significant public concern about the potential for humans to contract the disease. Experts were brought in to reassure the public, but as time passed, the urgency faded, yet the issue persisted. Consequently, increasing numbers of herd animals exhibited symptoms of BSE and had to be destroyed. Symptoms, however, may not manifest for years after the disease's onset, leading to the question: "If there are no symptoms, how can we be certain that infected animals aren't contaminating the food supply?" In response, the government claimed that safety precautions were sufficient to prevent infected beef from entering the food chain, a response that was vague and only heightened suspicion. A recent TV documentary later revealed that not only were infected animals being sent for slaughter, but also that safety measures were inadequate, and BSE-contaminated meat was being distributed nationwide. The government's denial of these findings exacerbated the situation, leaving the public unsure and hesitant to take the risk. Further complicating matters, recent media attention on isolated cases of CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease) has not alleviated public concern.

ii.) Concurrently, the rise of vegetarianism also contributes to the declining beef consumption in the U.K. More individuals are adopting plant-based diets, influenced by health, ethical, and environmental reasons. As a result, the demand for beef has decreased, complementing the apprehension surrounding BSE. Together, these factors have led to a noticeable shift in eating habits away from beef consumption among the U.K. population.

There are various reasons why people in the UK may decide to stop eating beef. Firstly, it may be in response to the protests at ports trying to prevent calves being exported where they may be used as veal calves and put into veal crates. These crates, which are uncomfortable for the animal and have been banned for many years in the UK, have prompted many people to either become vegetarian or at least stop eating beef. Scenes of calves in these crates or of protests, which have included tragic incidents such as the killing of a protester, have been widely covered on television and in newspapers. 

The emergence of BSE (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy), commonly known as 'mad cow disease,' and the linked (or possibly linked) CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease) have further alarmed consumers. Despite the risk of contracting CJD being minutely small and the number of cases per year remaining roughly the same, media hype has blown the disease out of proportion, causing many people to become wary of eating beef and resort to other products such as lamb.

The effect on the agricultural industry, particularly beef producers, is catastrophic. Prices have already decreased as much as 20p per kilogram at auction, which is a substantial loss given that an average beef animal will weigh around 500 kg. Many farmers may go out of business due to this loss in profits or may diversify into other products such as arable crops. This shift could potentially bring the price of beef back up in the future, but it may also exacerbate the problems of arable overproduction and increase storage costs for excess produce. Consequently, prices may fluctuate in the arable sector as more farmers shift their focus to crops.

Thus, the effects of people not eating beef will have a knock-on effect throughout large areas of the agricultural industry. Beef producers would find it increasingly difficult to make profits as they would need to increase sales to maintain revenue while also incurring the excess costs of food and other expenses such as bills. This situation may lead to labor redundancies, increasing unemployment and government benefit payments simultaneously. We see that the effects on the agricultural industry would be widespread.

The problem facing the Monarchy is how to adapt to modern life while still retaining a traditional role. The pressures of growing media coverage and ever more efficient ways of hearing and seeing what is intended to be private question the Monarchy's fitness to govern. The role is necessary in deciding who is to make a government, especially if there is a hung parliament, as the Queen will assess who can produce an effective government. Moreover, the activity in calling general elections is a right of the Monarchy, providing a useful role in the administration of the country. This may also prevent a prime minister from attempting to "cash in" on short-term popularity, such as if a war has just been won, as the Monarch can refuse to call such an election.

In Vitro fertilisation, commonly known as IVF, involves the fertilisation of an egg outside the body, in a laboratory setting. The egg is retrieved from the mother and placed in an environment designed to optimise the chances of fertilisation by sperm from the father. Once fertilisation occurs, the fertilised egg is implanted back into the mother's womb, kickstarting a normal pregnancy. Typically, more than one egg is retrieved from the mother to increase the chances of a successful pregnancy and, in some cases, to produce multiple births such as twins or triplets.

However, IVF is not without controversy. Some people argue that it is not natural, suggesting that life should only begin at the moment of conception. These individuals bring up ethical concerns, questioning who should receive the treatment, at what age it should be administered, and whether the significant costs associated with IVF could be better spent on life-saving measures, such as vaccinations against diseases like measles.

Proponents of IVF counter these arguments by stating that individuals have the right to decide if and when they want to have children. They highlight that IVF offers hope to women who, due to medical conditions like blocked fallopian tubes, might otherwise be unable to conceive. However, they also acknowledge the necessity for ethical considerations and regulations in the rapidly advancing field of reproductive technology.

In light of these advancements, it is crucial to establish certain guidelines to ensure ethical practices. One proposed regulation is that fertility treatments should not be given to post-menopausal women. The menopause is a biological indicator that a woman is no longer capable of bearing children. A notable case from last year involved a post-menopausal woman who obtained IVF by lying about her age, raising significant ethical and legal concerns.

In conclusion, while IVF provides valuable options for those struggling to conceive, it is essential to balance these benefits with ethical considerations and regulatory frameworks to guide its use responsibly.

In vitro fertilisation (IVF) is the fertilisation of the egg outside the mother's body in a laboratory environment. This has led to a moral dilemma: is it an acceptable start to a baby's life to begin outside the mother, and will it cause any damage? Moreover, one must consider if society could become overly dependent on this method of fertilisation.

Fertility treatment for post-menopausal women raises additional ethical questions. When women reach menopause, it does not necessarily mean their bodies are no longer suitable hosts for a new life. Thanks to advancements in medical technology, women can now successfully receive treatment and give birth to healthy children late in life. Although some British doctors disapproved of such methods, this treatment is easily available abroad. The desire to have children is so strong that mothers can pay thousands of pounds in hopes of conceiving. I find this issue challenging to agree or oppose, as only being young and having my life ahead makes it easy to see it as disgraceful for women in their late 50s to have children after missing earlier opportunities. Science has moved on dramatically since the C19th. Many new things have been invented, and many things medically have changed. Today, people can undergo liver, heart, and even lung transplants, despite the complications that may arise, many of which are successful. Additionally, individuals lacking sufficient blood supplies or white cells can receive whole new blood supplies or bone marrow transplants, respectively. All these procedures are performed on living people, but today, biological operations can also be carried out on humans who are not yet born.

In modern medicine, the process known as 'in vitro fertilisation' (IVF) enables the conception of a baby with remarkable precision. This technique involves removing an egg from a woman and placing it in a test tube. Sperm is then introduced to the test tube, and fertilization occurs as the egg and sperm fuse together. The test tube is incubated for several weeks until the embryo forms. Once the embryo is sufficiently developed, it is implanted back into the mother, allowing the fetus to grow naturally. This procedure is especially beneficial for married couples who have been unsuccessful in conceiving naturally, as it enables the baby to grow inside the mother's womb, fostering a deep bond that would not be possible through adoption.
